recommendation: Diagnosis and risk stratiﬁcation It is recommended to base diagnosis and initial short-term risk stratiﬁcation on a combination of clinical history, symptoms, vital signs, other physical ﬁndings, ECG, and laboratory results including hs-cTn.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-STsegment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: It is recommended to measure cardiac troponins with high-sensitivity assays immediately after admission and obtain the results within 60 min of blood sampling.3,1013,29
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-STsegment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: It is recommended to obtain a 12-lead ECG within 10 min after ﬁrst medical contact and to have it immediately interpreted by an experienced physician.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-STsegment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: It is recommended to obtain an additional 12-lead ECG in case of recurrent symptoms or diagnostic uncertainty.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-STsegment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Additional testing after 3 h is recommended if the ﬁrst two cardiac troponin measurements of the 0 h/1 h algorithm are not conclusive and the clinical condition is still suggestive of ACS.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-STsegment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: As an alternative to the
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-STsegment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Additional ECG leads (V3R, V4R, V7V9) are recommended if ongoing ischaemia is suspected when standard leads are inconclusive.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-STsegment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: As an alternative to the
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-STsegment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: The routine use of copeptin as an additional biomarker for the early rule-out of MI should be considered where hs-cTn assays are not available.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-STsegment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: It should be considered to use established risk scores for prognosis estimation.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-STsegment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: For initial diagnostic purposes, it is not recommended to routinely measure additional biomarkers such as h-FABP or copeptin, in addition to hs-cTn.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-STsegment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: In patients with no recurrence of chest pain, normal ECG ﬁndings, and normal levels of cardiac troponin (preferably high sensitivity), but still with a suspected ACS, a non-invasive stress test (preferably with imaging) for inducible ischaemia or CCTA is recommended before deciding on an invasive approach.91,92,98,101,105
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-STsegment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Echocardiography is recommended to evaluate regional and global LV function and to rule in or rule out differential diagnoses.c
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-STsegment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: CCTA is recommended as an alternative to ICA to exclude ACS when there is a low-to-intermediate likelihood of CAD and when cardiac troponin and/or ECG are normal or inconclusive.105,108,110
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-STsegment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Monitoring Continuous rhythm monitoring is recommended until the diagnosis of NSTEMI has been established or ruled out.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-STsegment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: It is recommended to admit NSTEMI patients to a monitored unit.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-STsegment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Rhythm monitoring up to 24 h or to PCI (whichever comes ﬁrst) is recommended in NSTEMI patients at low risk for cardiac arrhythmias.d
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-STsegment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Rhythm monitoring for >24 h is recommended in NSTEMI patients at increased risk for cardiac arrhythmias.e
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-STsegment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: In the absence of signs or symptoms of ongoing ischaemia, rhythm monitoring in unstable angina may be considered in selected patients (e.g. suspicion of coronary spasm or associated symptoms suggestive of arrhythmic events).
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-STsegment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Antiplatelet treatment Aspirin is recommended for all patients without contraindications at an initial oral LD of 150300 mg (or 75250 mg i.v.), and at a MD of 75100 mg o.d. for long-term treatment.179
table_name: antithrombotic treatment in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients without atrial ﬁbrillation undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention

recommendation: A P2Y12 receptor inhibitor is recommended in addition to aspirin, and maintained over 12 months unless there are contraindications or an excessive risk of bleeding.170,171,182 Options are:
table_name: antithrombotic treatment in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients without atrial ﬁbrillation undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention

recommendation:  Prasugrel in P2Y12 receptor inhibitor-naı¨ve patients proceeding to PCI (60 mg LD, 10 mg/d as standard dose, 5 mg/d for patients aged >_75 years or with a body weight <60 kg).
table_name: antithrombotic treatment in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients without atrial ﬁbrillation undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention

recommendation:  Ticagrelor irrespective of the planned treatment strategy (invasive or conservative) (180 mg LD, 90 mg b.i.d.).
table_name: antithrombotic treatment in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients without atrial ﬁbrillation undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention

recommendation:  Clopidogrel (300600 mg LD, 75 mg daily dose), only when prasugrel or ticagrelor are not available, cannot be tolerated, or are contraindicated.
table_name: antithrombotic treatment in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients without atrial ﬁbrillation undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention

recommendation: Prasugrel should be considered in preference to ticagrelor for NSTE-ACS patients who proceed to PCI.
table_name: antithrombotic treatment in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients without atrial ﬁbrillation undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention

recommendation: GP IIb/IIIa antagonists should be considered for bail-out if there is evidence of no-reﬂow or a thrombotic complication.
table_name: antithrombotic treatment in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients without atrial ﬁbrillation undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention

recommendation: Cangrelor may be considered in P2Y12 receptor inhibitor-naı¨ve patients undergoing PCI.184
table_name: antithrombotic treatment in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients without atrial ﬁbrillation undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention

recommendation: Pre-treatment with a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor may be considered in patients with NSTE-ACS who are not planned to undergo an early invasive strategy and do not have an HBR.
table_name: antithrombotic treatment in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients without atrial ﬁbrillation undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention

recommendation: Treatment with GP IIb/IIIa antagonists in patients in whom coronary anatomy is not known is not recommended.
table_name: antithrombotic treatment in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients without atrial ﬁbrillation undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention

recommendation: It is not recommended to administer routine pre-treatment with a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor in patients in whom coronary anatomy is not known and an early invasive management is planned.
table_name: antithrombotic treatment in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients without atrial ﬁbrillation undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention

recommendation: Peri-interventional anticoagulant treatment Parenteral anticoagulation is recommended for all patients, in addition to antiplatelet treatment, at the time of diagnosis and, especially, during revascularization procedures according to both ischaemic and bleeding risks.
table_name: antithrombotic treatment in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients without atrial ﬁbrillation undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention

recommendation: UFH (weight-adjusted i.v. bolus during PCI of 70100 IU/kg, or 5070 IU/kg in combination with a GP IIb/IIIa inhibitor; activated clotting time target range of 250350 s, or 200250 s if a GP IIb/IIIa inhibitor is given) is recommended in patients undergoing PCI.
table_name: antithrombotic treatment in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients without atrial ﬁbrillation undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention

recommendation: In cases of medical treatment or logistical constraints for transferring the patient to PCI within the required time frame, fondaparinux is recommended and, in such cases, a single bolus of UFH is recommended at the time of PCI.
table_name: antithrombotic treatment in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients without atrial ﬁbrillation undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention

recommendation: It is recommended to select anticoagulation according to both ischaemic and bleeding risks, and according to the efﬁcacysafety proﬁle of the chosen agent.
table_name: antithrombotic treatment in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients without atrial ﬁbrillation undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention

recommendation: Enoxaparin (i.v.) should be considered in patients pre-treated with subcutaneous enoxaparin.194
table_name: antithrombotic treatment in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients without atrial ﬁbrillation undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention

recommendation: Discontinuation of parenteral anticoagulation should be considered immediately after an invasive procedure.
table_name: antithrombotic treatment in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients without atrial ﬁbrillation undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention

recommendation: Bivalirudin may be considered as an alternative to UFH.
table_name: antithrombotic treatment in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients without atrial ﬁbrillation undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention

recommendation: Crossover of UFH and LMWH is not recommended.
table_name: antithrombotic treatment in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients without atrial ﬁbrillation undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention

recommendation: In patients with NSTE-ACS treated with coronary stent implantation, DAPT with a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor on top of aspirin is recommended for 12 months unless there are contraindications such as excessive risk of bleeding.
table_name: post-interventional and maintenance treatment in patients with non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Prolonging antithrombotic treatment duration Adding a second antithrombotic agent to aspirin for extended long-term secondary prevention should be considered in patients with a high risk of ischaemic events and without increased risk of major or life-threatening bleeding (see Tables 9 and 11 for options).
table_name: post-interventional and maintenance treatment in patients with non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Adding a second antithrombotic agent to aspirin for extended long-term secondary prevention may be considered in patients with moderately increased risk of ischaemic events and without increased risk of major or life-threatening bleeding (see Tables 9 and 11 for options).
table_name: post-interventional and maintenance treatment in patients with non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: In ACS patients with no prior stroke/transient ischaemic attack who are at high ischaemic risk and low bleeding risk and are receiving aspirin and clopidogrel, low-dose rivaroxaban (2.5 mg b.i.d. for approximately 1 year) may be considered after discontinuation of parenteral anticoagulation.
table_name: post-interventional and maintenance treatment in patients with non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Shortening antithrombotic treatment duration After stent implantation with high risk of bleeding (e.g. PRECISE-DAPT >_25 or ARC-HBR criteria met), discontinuation of P2Y12 receptor inhibitor therapy after 3 months should be considered.
table_name: post-interventional and maintenance treatment in patients with non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: After stent implantation in patients undergoing a strategy of DAPT, stopping aspirin after 36 months should be considered, depending on the balance between the ischaemic and bleeding risk.
table_name: post-interventional and maintenance treatment in patients with non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: De-escalation of P2Y12 receptor inhibitor treatment (e.g. with a switch from prasugrel or ticagrelor to clopidogrel) may be considered as an alternative DAPT strategy, especially for ACS patients deemed unsuitable for potent platelet inhibition. De-escalation may be done unguided based on clinical judgment or guided by platelet function testing or CYP2C19 genotyping, depending on patient’s risk proﬁle and availability of respective assays.
table_name: post-interventional and maintenance treatment in patients with non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Sublingual or i.v. nitrates and early initiation of beta-blocker treatment are recommended in patients with ongoing ischaemic symptoms and without contraindications.
table_name: anti-ischaemic drugs in the acute phase of non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: It is recommended to continue chronic betablocker therapy unless the patient is in overt heart failure.
table_name: anti-ischaemic drugs in the acute phase of non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: i.v. nitrates are recommended in patients with uncontrolled hypertension or signs of heart failure.
table_name: anti-ischaemic drugs in the acute phase of non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: In patients with suspected/conﬁrmed vasospastic angina, calcium channel blockers and nitrates should be considered and beta-blockers avoided.
table_name: anti-ischaemic drugs in the acute phase of non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Stroke prevention is recommended to AF patients with >_1 non-sex CHA2DS2-VASc stroke risk factors (score of >_1 in males or >_2 in females).For patients with >_2 non-sex stroke risk factors, OAC is recommended.255
table_name: combining antiplatelet agents and anticoagulants in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients requiring chronic oral anticoagulation

recommendation: For patients with 1 non-sex stroke risk factor, OAC should be considered and treatment may be individualized based on net clinical beneﬁt and consideration of patient values and preferences.260
table_name: combining antiplatelet agents and anticoagulants in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients requiring chronic oral anticoagulation

recommendation: An early ICA should be considered in HBR patients, irrespective of OAC exposure, to expedite treatment allocation (medical vs. PCI vs. CABG) and to determine the optimal antithrombotic regimen.
table_name: combining antiplatelet agents and anticoagulants in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients requiring chronic oral anticoagulation

recommendation: Patients undergoing coronary stenting Anticoagulation During PCI, additional parenteral anticoagulation is recommended, irrespective of the timing of the last dose of all NOACs and if INR is <2.5 in VKA-treated patients.
table_name: combining antiplatelet agents and anticoagulants in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients requiring chronic oral anticoagulation

recommendation: In patients with an indication for OAC with VKA in combination with aspirin and/or clopidogrel, the dose intensity of VKA should be carefully regulated with a target INR of 2.02.5 and a time in the therapeutic range >70%.236,238
table_name: combining antiplatelet agents and anticoagulants in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients requiring chronic oral anticoagulation

recommendation: Uninterrupted therapeutic anticoagulation with VKA or NOACs should be considered during the periprocedural phase.
table_name: combining antiplatelet agents and anticoagulants in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients requiring chronic oral anticoagulation

recommendation: Antiplatelet treatment In patients with AF and CHA2DS2-VASc score >_1 in men and >_2 in women, after a short period of TAT (up to 1 week from the acute event), DAT is recommended as the default strategy using a NOAC at the recommended dose for stroke prevention and a single oral antiplatelet agent (preferably clopidogrel).238
table_name: combining antiplatelet agents and anticoagulants in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients requiring chronic oral anticoagulation

recommendation: Periprocedural DAPT administration consisting of aspirin and clopidogrel up to 1 week is recommended.238
table_name: combining antiplatelet agents and anticoagulants in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients requiring chronic oral anticoagulation

recommendation: Discontinuation of antiplatelet treatment in patients treated with an OAC is recommended after 12 months.236
table_name: combining antiplatelet agents and anticoagulants in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients requiring chronic oral anticoagulation

recommendation: In patients treated with a VKA (e.g. mechanical prosthetic valves), clopidogrel alone should be considered in selected patients (HAS-BLED >_3 or ARC-HBR met and low risk of stent thrombosis) for up to 12 months.
table_name: combining antiplatelet agents and anticoagulants in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients requiring chronic oral anticoagulation

recommendation: When rivaroxaban is used and concerns about HBR prevail over stent thrombosis or ischaemic stroke, rivaroxaban 15 mg o.d. should be considered in preference to rivaroxaban 20 mg o.d. for the duration of concomitant SAPT or DAPT.
table_name: combining antiplatelet agents and anticoagulants in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients requiring chronic oral anticoagulation

recommendation: In patients at HBR (HAS-BLED >_3), dabigatran 110 mg b.i.d. should be considered in preference to dabigatran 150 mg b.i.d. for the duration of concomitant SAPT or DAPT to mitigate bleeding risk.
table_name: combining antiplatelet agents and anticoagulants in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients requiring chronic oral anticoagulation

recommendation: In patients treated with an OAC, aspirin plus clopidogrel for longer than 1 week and up to 1 month should be considered in those with high ischaemic risk or other anatomical/procedural characteristics which outweigh the bleeding risk (Table 11).
table_name: combining antiplatelet agents and anticoagulants in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients requiring chronic oral anticoagulation

recommendation: DAT (with an OAC and either ticagrelor or prasugrel) may be considered as an alternative to TAT (with an OAC, aspirin, and clopidogrel) in patients with a moderate or high risk of stent thrombosis, irrespective of the type of stent used.
table_name: combining antiplatelet agents and anticoagulants in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients requiring chronic oral anticoagulation

recommendation: The use of ticagrelor or prasugrel as part of TAT is not recommended.
table_name: combining antiplatelet agents and anticoagulants in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients requiring chronic oral anticoagulation

recommendation: Medically managed patients One antiplatelet agent in addition to an OAC should be considered for up to 1 year.
table_name: combining antiplatelet agents and anticoagulants in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients requiring chronic oral anticoagulation

recommendation: In patients with AF, apixaban 5 mg b.i.d. and SAPT (clopidogrel) for at least 6 months may be considered.
table_name: combining antiplatelet agents and anticoagulants in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients requiring chronic oral anticoagulation

recommendation: In patients with dabigatran-associated ongoing life-threatening bleeding, the administration of the speciﬁc antidote for dabigatran  idarucizumab  should be considered.
table_name: bleeding management and blood transfusion in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndromes for anticoagulated patients

recommendation: In patients with VKA-associated life-threatening bleeding events, rapid reversal of anticoagulation with four-factor prothrombin complex concentrate rather than with fresh frozen plasma or recombinant activated factor VII should be considered. In addition, repetitive 10 mg i.v. doses of vitamin K should be administered by slow injection.
table_name: bleeding management and blood transfusion in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndromes for anticoagulated patients

recommendation: In patients with NOAC-associated ongoing life-threatening bleeding, the administration of prothrombin complex concentrates or activated prothrombin complex concentrates should be considered when the speciﬁc antidote is unavailable.
table_name: bleeding management and blood transfusion in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndromes for anticoagulated patients

recommendation: In patients with rivaroxaban-, apixaban-, or edoxaban-associated ongoing life-threatening bleeding, the administration of the speciﬁc antidote  andexanet-alpha  may be considered.
table_name: bleeding management and blood transfusion in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndromes for anticoagulated patients

recommendation: In patients with anaemia and no evidence of active bleeding, blood transfusion may be considered in case of compromised haemodynamic status, haematocrit <25%, or haemoglobin level <8 g/dL.
table_name: bleeding management and blood transfusion in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndromes for anticoagulated patients

recommendation: Timing of invasive strategy An immediate invasive strategy (<2 h) is recommended in patients with at least one of the following very high-risk criteria: • Haemodynamic instability or CS. • Recurrent or refractory chest pain despite medical treatment. • Life-threatening arrhythmias. • Mechanical complications of MI. • Heart failure clearly related to NSTE-ACS. • Presence of ST-segment depression >1 mm in >_6 leads additional to ST-segment elevation in aVR and/or V1.

An early invasive strategy within 24 h is recommended in patients with any of the following highrisk criteria: • Diagnosis of NSTEMI suggested by the diagnostic algorithm recommended in section 3. • Dynamic or presumably new contiguous ST/T-segment changes suggesting ongoing ischaemia. • Transient ST-segment elevation.273,362 • GRACE risk score >140.
A selective invasive strategy after appropriate ischaemia testing or detection of obstructive CAD by CCTA is recommended in patients considered at low risk.
Delayed as opposed to immediate angiography should be considered among haemodynamically stable patients without ST-segment elevation successfully resuscitated after out-of-hospital cardiac arrest.

DES are recommended over bare-metal stents for any PCI irrespective of: • Clinical presentation. • Lesion type. • Planned non-cardiac surgery. • Anticipated duration of DAPT. • Concomitant anticoagulant therapy.

It is recommended to base the revascularization strategy (ad hoc culprit lesion PCI/multivessel PCI/ CABG) on the patient’s clinical status and comorbidities, as well as their disease severity [i.e. the distribution and angiographic lesion characteristics (e.g. SYNTAX score)], according to the principles for stable CAD.350 However, the decision on immediate PCI of the culprit stenosis does not require Heart Team consultation.
Complete revascularization should be considered in NSTE-ACS patients without CS and with multivessel CAD.
Intracoronary imaging should be considered to diagnose SCAD if suspected.
Complete revascularization during index PCI may be considered in NSTE-ACS patients with multivessel disease.
FFR-guided revascularization of a non-culprit NSTE-ACS lesion may be used during index PCI.
In all patients with an initial working diagnosis of MINOCA, it is recommended to follow a diagnostic algorithm to differentiate true MINOCA from alternative diagnoses.
table_name: myocardial infarction with non-obstructive coronary arteries

recommendation: It is recommended to perform CMR in all MINOCA patients without an obvious underlying cause.
table_name: myocardial infarction with non-obstructive coronary arteries

recommendation: It is recommended to manage patients with an initial diagnosis of MINOCA and a ﬁnal established underlying cause according to the disease-speciﬁc guidelines.
table_name: myocardial infarction with non-obstructive coronary arteries

recommendation: Patients with a ﬁnal diagnosis of MINOCA of unknown cause may be treated according to secondary prevention guidelines for atherosclerotic disease.
table_name: myocardial infarction with non-obstructive coronary arteries

recommendation: Emergency coronary angiography is recommended in patients with CS complicating ACS.
table_name: non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients with heart failure or cardiogenic shock

recommendation: Emergency PCI of the culprit lesion is recommended for patients with CS due to NSTE-ACS, independent of the time delay from symptom onset, if the coronary anatomy is amenable to PCI.
table_name: non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients with heart failure or cardiogenic shock

recommendation: Emergency CABG is recommended for patients with CS if the coronary anatomy is not amenable to PCI.
table_name: non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients with heart failure or cardiogenic shock

recommendation: It is recommended to perform emergency echocardiography without delay to assess LV and valvular function and exclude mechanical complications.
table_name: non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients with heart failure or cardiogenic shock

recommendation: In cases of haemodynamic instability, emergency surgical or catheter-based repair of mechanical complications of ACS is recommended, as decided by the Heart Team.
table_name: non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients with heart failure or cardiogenic shock

recommendation: For NSTE-ACS-related mechanical complications, the use of IABP should be considered.
table_name: non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients with heart failure or cardiogenic shock

recommendation: In selected patients with ACS and CS, short-term mechanical circulatory support may be considered, depending on patient age, comorbidities, neurological function, and the prospects for longterm survival and predicted quality of life.
table_name: non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients with heart failure or cardiogenic shock

recommendation: Routine use of IABP in patients with CS and no mechanical complications due to ACS is not recommended.
table_name: non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients with heart failure or cardiogenic shock

recommendation: Routine immediate revascularization of non-culprit lesions in NSTE-ACS patients with multivessel disease presenting with CS is not recommended.
table_name: non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients with heart failure or cardiogenic shock

recommendation: It is recommended to screen all patients with NSTE-ACS for diabetes and to monitor blood glucose levels frequently in patients with known diabetes or admission hyperglycaemia.
table_name: diabetes mellitus in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients

recommendation: Avoidance of hypoglycaemia is recommended.424
table_name: diabetes mellitus in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients

recommendation: Glucose-lowering therapy should be considered in ACS patients with blood glucose >10 mmol/L (>180 mg/dL), with the target adapted to comorbidities, while episodes of hypoglycaemia should be avoided.422,428
table_name: diabetes mellitus in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients

recommendation: A multifactorial approach to diabetes mellitus management, with treatment targets, should be considered in patients with diabetes and CVD.431
table_name: diabetes mellitus in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients

recommendation: Less stringent glucose control should be considered, both in the acute phase and at follow-up, in patients with more advanced CVD, older age, longer diabetes duration, and more comorbidities.
table_name: diabetes mellitus in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients

recommendation: Risk stratiﬁcation in CKD It is recommended to apply the same diagnostic and therapeutic strategies in patients with CKD (dose adjustment may be necessary) as for patients with normal renal function.
table_name: patients with chronic kidney disease and non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: It is recommended to assess kidney function by eGFR in all patients.
table_name: patients with chronic kidney disease and non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Myocardial revascularization in patients with CKD Use of low- or iso-osmolar contrast media (at lowest possible volume) are recommended in invasive strategies.
table_name: patients with chronic kidney disease and non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Pre- and post-hydration with isotonic saline should be considered if the expected contrast volume is >100 mL in invasive strategies.
table_name: patients with chronic kidney disease and non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: As an alternative to the pre- and post-hydration regimen, tailored hydration regimens may be considered.
table_name: patients with chronic kidney disease and non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: CABG should be considered over PCI in patients with multivessel CAD whose surgical risk proﬁle is acceptable and life expectancy is >1 year.
table_name: patients with chronic kidney disease and non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: It is recommended to apply the same diagnostic strategies in older patients as for younger patients.
table_name: older persons with non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: It is recommended to apply the same interventional strategies in older patients as for younger patients.
table_name: older persons with non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: The choice of antithrombotic agent and dosage, as well as secondary preventions, should be adapted to renal function, as well as speciﬁc contraindications.
table_name: older persons with non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Improvement of lifestyle factors in addition to appropriate pharmacological management is recommended in order to reduce allcause and cardiovascular mortality and morbidity and improve health-related quality of life.487
table_name: lifestyle managements after non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Cognitive behavioural interventions are recommended to help individuals achieve a healthy lifestyle.498
table_name: lifestyle managements after non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Multidisciplinary exercise-based cardiac rehabilitation is recommended as an effective means for patients with CAD to achieve a healthy lifestyle and manage risk factors in order to reduce all-cause and cardiovascular mortality and morbidity, and improve healthrelated quality of life.
table_name: lifestyle managements after non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Involvement of multidisciplinary healthcare professionals (cardiologists, general practitioners, nurses, dieticians, physiotherapists, psychologists, pharmacists) is recommended in order to reduce all-cause and cardiovascular mortality and morbidity, and improve health-related quality of life.
table_name: lifestyle managements after non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Psychological interventions are recommended to improve symptoms of depression in patients with CAD in order to improve healthrelated quality of life.
table_name: lifestyle managements after non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Annual inﬂuenza vaccination is recommended for patients with CAD, especially in the older person, in order to improve morbidity.505
table_name: lifestyle managements after non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Lipid-lowering drugs Statins are recommended in all NSTE-ACS patients. The aim is to reduce LDL-C by >_50% from baseline and to achieve LDL-C <1.4 mmol/L (<55 mg/ dL).
table_name: pharmacological long-term management after non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome (excluding antithrombotic treatments)

recommendation: If the LDL-C goalc is not achieved after 46 weeks with the maximally tolerated statin dose, combination with ezetimibe is recommended.
table_name: pharmacological long-term management after non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome (excluding antithrombotic treatments)

recommendation: If the LDL-C goalc is not achieved after 46 weeks despite maximally tolerated statin therapy and ezetimibe, the addition of a PCSK9 inhibitor is recommended.
table_name: pharmacological long-term management after non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome (excluding antithrombotic treatments)

recommendation: If the current NSTE-ACS episode is a recurrence within less than 2 years of a ﬁrst ACS, while taking maximally tolerated statin-based therapy, an LDL-C goal of <1.0 mmol/L (<40 mg/dL) may be considered.
table_name: pharmacological long-term management after non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome (excluding antithrombotic treatments)

recommendation: ACE inhibitors or ARBs ACE inhibitors (or ARBs in cases of intolerance to ACE inhibitors) are recommended in patients with heart failure with reduced LVEF (<40%), diabetes, or CKD unless contraindicated (e.g. severe renal impairment, hyperkalaemia, etc.) in order to reduce allcause and cardiovascular mortality and cardiovascular morbidity.536
table_name: pharmacological long-term management after non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome (excluding antithrombotic treatments)

recommendation: Beta-blockers Beta-blockers are recommended in patients with systolic LV dysfunction or heart failure with reduced LVEF (<40%).539
table_name: pharmacological long-term management after non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome (excluding antithrombotic treatments)

recommendation: In patients with prior MI, long-term oral treatment with a beta-blocker should be considered in order to reduce all-cause and cardiovascular mortality and cardiovascular morbidity.542
table_name: pharmacological long-term management after non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome (excluding antithrombotic treatments)

recommendation: MRAs MRAs are recommended in patients with heart failure with reduced LVEF (<40%) in order to reduce allcause and cardiovascular mortality and cardiovascular morbidity.
table_name: pharmacological long-term management after non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome (excluding antithrombotic treatments)

recommendation: Proton pump inhibitors Concomitant use of a proton pump inhibitor is recommended in patients receiving aspirin monotherapy, DAPT, DAT, TAT, or OAC monotherapy who are at high risk of gastrointestinal bleeding in order to reduce the risk of gastric bleeds.
table_name: pharmacological long-term management after non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome (excluding antithrombotic treatments)

recommendation: Diagnosis and risk stratiﬁcation It is recommended to base diagnosis and initial short-term risk stratiﬁcation on a combination of clinical history, symptoms, vital signs, other physical ﬁndings, ECG, and laboratory results including hs-cTn.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: It is recommended to measure cardiac troponins with high-sensitivity assays immediately after admission and obtain the results within 60 min of blood sampling.3,1013,29
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: It is recommended to obtain a 12-lead ECG within 10 min after ﬁrst medical contact and to have it immediately interpreted by an experienced physician.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: It is recommended to obtain an additional 12-lead ECG in case of recurrent symptoms or diagnostic uncertainty.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Additional testing after 3 h is recommended if the ﬁrst two cardiac troponin measurements of the 0 h/1 h algorithm are not conclusive and the clinical condition is still suggestive of ACS.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: As an alternative to the
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Additional ECG leads (V3R, V4R, V7V9) are recommended if ongoing ischaemia is suspected when standard leads are inconclusive.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: For initial diagnostic purposes, it is not recommended to routinely measure additional biomarkers such as h-FABP or copeptin, in addition to hs-cTn.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Imaging In patients presenting with cardiac arrest or haemodynamic instability of presumed cardiovascular origin, echocardiography is recommended and should be performed by trained physicians immediately following a 12-lead ECG.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: In patients with no recurrence of chest pain, normal ECG ﬁndings, and normal levels of cardiac troponin (preferably high sensitivity), but still with a suspected ACS, a non-invasive stress test (preferably with imaging) for inducible ischaemia or CCTA is recommended before deciding on an invasive approach.91,92,98,101,105
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Echocardiography is recommended to evaluate regional and global LV function and to rule in or rule out differential diagnoses.c
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: CCTA is recommended as an alternative to ICA to exclude ACS when there is a low-to-intermediate likelihood of CAD and when cardiac troponin and/or ECG are normal or inconclusive.105,108,110
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Monitoring Continuous rhythm monitoring is recommended until the diagnosis of NSTEMI has been established or ruled out.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: It is recommended to admit NSTEMI patients to a monitored unit.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Rhythm monitoring up to 24 h or to PCI (whichever comes ﬁrst) is recommended in NSTEMI patients at low risk for cardiac arrhythmias.d
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Rhythm monitoring for >24 h is recommended in NSTEMI patients at increased risk for cardiac arrhythmias.e
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Recommendations on biomarker measurements for prognostic stratiﬁcation Beyond its diagnostic role, it is recommended to measure hs-cTn serially for the estimation of prognosis.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: The measurement of additional biomarkers, such as mid-regional pro-A-type natriuretic peptide, high-sensitivity C-reactive protein, mid-regional pro-adrenomedullin, GDF-15, copeptin, and h-FABP is not recommended for routine risk or prognosis assessment.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Recommendations for antithrombotic treatment in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention Antiplatelet treatment Aspirin is recommended for all patients without contraindications at an initial oral LD of 150300 mg (or 75250 mg i.v.), and at a MD of 75100 mg o.d. for long-term treatment.179
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: A P2Y12 receptor inhibitor is recommended in addition to aspirin, and maintained over 12 months unless there are contraindications or an excessive risk of bleeding.170,171,182 Options are:
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation:  Prasugrel in P2Y12 receptor inhibitor-naı¨ve patients proceeding to PCI (60 mg LD, 10 mg/d as standard dose, 5 mg/d for patients aged >_75 years or with a body weight <60 kg).
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation:  Ticagrelor irrespective of the planned treatment strategy (invasive or conservative) (180 mg LD, 90 mg b.i.d.).
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation:  Clopidogrel (300600 mg LD, 75 mg daily dose), only when prasugrel or ticagrelor are not available, cannot be tolerated, or are contraindicated.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Treatment with GP IIb/IIIa antagonists in patients in whom coronary anatomy is not known and is not recommended.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: It is not recommended to administer routine pre-treatment with a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor in patients in whom coronary anatomy is not known and an early invasive management is planned.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Peri-interventional anticoagulant treatment Parenteral anticoagulation is recommended for all patients, in addition to antiplatelet treatment, at the time of diagnosis and, especially, during revascularization procedures according to both ischaemic and bleeding risks.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: UFH (weight-adjusted i.v. bolus during PCI of 70100 IU/kg, or 5070 IU/kg in combination with a GP IIb/IIIa inhibitor; activated clotting time target range of 250350 s, or 200250 s if a GP IIb/IIIa inhibitor is given) is recommended in patients undergoing PCI.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: In cases of medical treatment or logistical constraints for transferring the patient to PCI within the required time frame, fondaparinux is recommended and, in such cases, a single bolus of UFH is recommended at the time of PCI.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Crossover of UFH and LMWH is not recommended.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Recommendations for post-interventional and maintenance treatment in patients with non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome In patients with NSTE-ACS treated with coronary stent implantation, DAPT with a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor on top of aspirin is recommended for 12 months unless there are contraindications such as excessive risk of bleeding.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Recommendations for anti-ischaemic drugs in the acute phase of non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome Sublingual or i.v. nitrates and early initiation of beta-blocker treatment are recommended in patients with ongoing ischaemic symptoms and without contraindications.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: It is recommended to continue chronic beta-blocker therapy unless the patient is in overt heart failure.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: i.v. nitrates are recommended in patients with uncontrolled hypertension or signs of heart failure.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Recommendations for combining antiplatelet agents and anticoagulants in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients requiring chronic oral anticoagulation Stroke prevention should be offered to AF patients with >_1 non-sex CHA2DS2-VASc stroke risk factors (score of >_1 in males or >_2 in females). For patients with >_2 non-sex stroke risk factors, OAC is recommended.255
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Patients undergoing coronary stenting Anticoagulation During PCI, additional parenteral anticoagulation is recommended, irrespective of the timing of the last dose of all NOACs and if INR is <2.5 in VKA-treated patients.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Antiplatelet treatment In patients with AF and CHA2DS2-VASc score >_1 in men and >_2 in women, after a short period of TAT (up to 1 week from the acute event), DAT is recommended as the default strategy using a NOAC at the recommended dose for stroke prevention and a single oral antiplatelet agent (preferably clopidogrel).238
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Periprocedural DAPT administration consisting of aspirin and clopidogrel up to 1 week is recommended.238
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Discontinuation of antiplatelet treatment in patients treated with an OAC is recommended after 12 months.236
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: The use of ticagrelor or prasugrel as part of TAT is not recommended.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Recommendations for coronary revascularization Timing of invasive strategy An immediate invasive strategy (<2 h) is recommended in patients with at least one of the following very high-risk criteria: • Haemodynamic instability or CS. • Recurrent or refractory chest pain despite medical treatment. • Life-threatening arrhythmias. • Mechanical complications of MI. • Heart failure clearly related to NSTE-ACS. • Presence of ST-segment depression >1 mm in >_6 leads additional to ST-segment elevation in aVR and/or V1.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: An early invasive strategy within 24 h is recommended in patients with any of the following high-risk criteria: • Diagnosis of NSTEMI suggested by the diagnostic algorithm recommended in section 3. • Dynamic or presumably new contiguous ST/T-segment changes suggesting ongoing ischaemia. • Transient ST-segment elevation.273,362 • GRACE risk score >140.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: A selective invasive strategy after appropriate ischaemia testing or detection of obstructive CAD by CCTA is recommended in patients considered at low risk.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Technical aspects Radial access is recommended as the standard approach, unless there are overriding procedural considerations.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: DES are recommended over bare-metal stents for any PCI irrespective of: • Clinical presentation. • Lesion type. • Planned non-cardiac surgery. • Anticipated duration of DAPT. • Concomitant anticoagulant therapy.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Recommendations for myocardial infarction with non-obstructive coronary arteries In all patients with an initial working diagnosis of MINOCA, it is recommended to follow a diagnostic algorithm to differentiate true MINOCA from alternative diagnoses.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: It is recommended to perform CMR in all MINOCA patients without an obvious underlying cause.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: It is recommended to manage patients with an initial diagnosis of MINOCA and a ﬁnal established underlying cause according to the disease-speciﬁc guidelines.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Recommendations for non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients with heart failure or cardiogenic shock Emergency coronary angiography is recommended in patients with CS complicating ACS.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Emergency PCI of the culprit lesion is recommended for patients with CS due to NSTE-ACS, independent of the time delay from symptom onset, if the coronary anatomy is amenable to PCI.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Emergency CABG is recommended for patients with CS if the coronary anatomy is not amenable to PCI.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: It is recommended to perform emergency echocardiography without delay to assess LV and valvular function and exclude mechanical complications.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: In cases of haemodynamic instability, emergency surgical or catheter-based repair of mechanical complications of ACS is recommended, as decided by the Heart Team.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Routine use of IABP in patients with CS and no mechanical complications due to ACS is not recommended.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Routine immediate revascularization of non-culprit lesions in NSTE-ACS patients with multivessel disease presenting with CS is not recommended.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Recommendations for diabetes mellitus in non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome patients It is recommended to screen all patients with NSTE-ACS for diabetes and to monitor blood glucose levels frequently in patients with known diabetes or admission hyperglycaemia.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Avoidance of hypoglycaemia is recommended.424
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Recommendations for patients with chronic kidney disease and non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome Risk stratiﬁcation in CKD It is recommended to apply the same diagnostic and therapeutic strategies in patients with CKD (dose adjustment may be necessary) as for patients with normal renal function.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: It is recommended to assess kidney function by eGFR in all patients.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Myocardial revascularization in patients with CKD Use of low- or iso-osmolar contrast media (at lowest possible volume) are recommended in invasive strategies.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Recommendations for older persons with non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome It is recommended to apply the same diagnostic strategies in older patients as for younger patients.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: It is recommended to apply the same interventional strategies in older patients as for younger patients.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: The choice of antithrombotic agent and dosage, as well as secondary preventions, should be adapted to renal function, as well as speciﬁc contraindications.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Recommendations for lifestyle managements after non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome Improvement of lifestyle factors in addition to appropriate pharmacological management is recommended in order to reduce allcause and cardiovascular mortality and morbidity and improve health-related quality of life.487
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Cognitive behavioural interventions are recommended to help individuals achieve a healthy lifestyle.498
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Multidisciplinary exercise-based cardiac rehabilitation is recommended as an effective means for patients with CAD to achieve a healthy lifestyle and manage risk factors in order to reduce all-cause and cardiovascular mortality and morbidity, and improve healthrelated quality of life.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Involvement of multidisciplinary healthcare professionals (cardiologists, general practitioners, nurses, dieticians, physiotherapists, psychologists, pharmacists) is recommended in order to reduce all-cause and cardiovascular mortality and morbidity, and improve health-related quality of life.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Psychological interventions are recommended to improve symptoms of depression in patients with CAD in order to improve healthrelated quality of life.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Annual inﬂuenza vaccination is recommended for patients with CAD, especially in the older person, in order to improve morbidity.505
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: If the LDL-C goalf is not achieved after 46 weeks with the maximally tolerated statin dose, combination with ezetimibe is recommended.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: If the LDL-C goalf is not achieved after 46 weeks despite maximally tolerated statin therapy and ezetimibe, the addition of a PCSK9 inhibitor is recommended.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: ACE inhibitors or ARBs ACE inhibitors (or ARBs in cases of intolerance to ACE inhibitors) are recommended in patients with heart failure with reduced LVEF (<40%), diabetes, or CKD unless contraindicated (e.g. severe renal impairment, hyperkalaemia, etc.) in order to reduce all-cause and cardiovascular mortality and cardiovascular morbidity.536
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Beta-blockers Beta-blockers are recommended in patients with systolic LV dysfunction or heart failure with reduced LVEF (<40%).539
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: MRAs MRAs are recommended in patients with heart failure with reduced LVEF (<40%) in order to reduce all-cause and cardiovascular mortality and cardiovascular morbidity.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: Proton pump inhibitors Concomitant use of a proton pump inhibitor is recommended in patients receiving aspirin monotherapy, DAPT, DAT, TAT, or OAC monotherapy who are at high risk of gastrointestinal bleeding in order to reduce the risk of gastric bleeds.
table_name: diagnosis, risk stratiﬁcation, imaging, and rhythm monitoring in patients with suspected non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome

recommendation: In patients with moderate and severe CHD complexity (Table 4) and documented arrhythmias, referral to a centre with a multidisciplinary team and expertise in ACHD patients and ACHDrelated arrhythmia is indicated.
table_name: treatment of arrhythmias in adult congenital heart disease

recommendation: In CHD patients with documented arrhythmias or at high risk for post-procedural arrhythmias (e.g. ASD closure at older age) considered for percutaneous or surgical (re)interventions, referral to a centre with a multidisciplinary team with expertise in these interventions and in invasive treatment of arrhythmias is indicated.
table_name: treatment of arrhythmias in adult congenital heart disease

recommendation: In mild CHD, catheter ablation is recommended over long-term medical therapy for symptomatic, sustained recurrent SVT (AVNRT, AVRT, AT, and IART), or if SVT is potentially related to SCD (Table 7).
table_name: treatment of arrhythmias in adult congenital heart disease

recommendation: In moderate and severe CHD, catheter ablation should be considered for symptomatic, sustained recurrent SVT (AVNRT, AVRT, AT, and IART), or if SVT is potentially related to SCD (Table 7), provided that the procedure is performed in experienced centres.
table_name: treatment of arrhythmias in adult congenital heart disease

recommendation: Catheter ablation should be considered for symptomatic, monomorphic sustained VT in patients for whom medical therapy is not desired, provided that the procedure is performed in experienced centres.
table_name: treatment of arrhythmias in adult congenital heart disease

recommendation: Implantable cardiac deﬁbrillator ICD implantation is indicated in adults with CHD who are survivors of an aborted cardiac arrest due to VF or haemodynamically untolerated VT after evaluation to deﬁne the cause of the event and exclusion of reversible causes.
table_name: treatment of arrhythmias in adult congenital heart disease

recommendation: ICD implantation is indicated in adults with CHD and sustained VT after haemodynamic evaluation and repair when indicated. EP evaluation is required to identify patients in whom catheter ablation or surgical ablation may be beneﬁcial as adjunctive treatment or in whom it may offer a reasonable alternative.
table_name: treatment of arrhythmias in adult congenital heart disease

recommendation: ICD implantation should be considered in adults with CHD with biventricular physiology and a systemic LV presenting with symptomatic heart failure (NYHA II/III) and EF <_35% despite >_ 3 months of optimal medical treatment, provided they are expected to survive substantially longer than one year with good functional status.c
table_name: treatment of arrhythmias in adult congenital heart disease

recommendation: ICD implantation should be considered in patients with CHD and unexplained syncope and suspicion for arrhythmia aetiology and either advanced ventricular dysfunction or inducible VT/VF at programmed electrical stimulation.
table_name: treatment of arrhythmias in adult congenital heart disease

recommendation: ICD implantation should be considered in selected TOF patients with multiple risk factors for SCD, including LV dysfunction, non-sustained, symptomatic VT, QRS duration >_180 ms, extensive RV scarring on CMR, or inducible VT at programmed electrical stimulation.
table_name: treatment of arrhythmias in adult congenital heart disease

recommendation: ICD implantation may be considered in patients with advanced single or systemic RV dysfunction (EF systemic RV <35%) in the presence of additional risk factors.d
table_name: treatment of arrhythmias in adult congenital heart disease

recommendation: Pacemaker PM implantation should be considered in ACHD patients with bradycardia-tachycardia syndrome to prevent IART, if ablation fails or is not possible.
table_name: treatment of arrhythmias in adult congenital heart disease

recommendation: PM implantation should be considered for patients with severe CHD and sinus or
table_name: treatment of arrhythmias in adult congenital heart disease

recommendation: PM implantation may be considered for patients with moderate CHD and sinus or junctional bradycardia (daytime heart rate <40 beats per minute or pauses >3 s).
table_name: treatment of arrhythmias in adult congenital heart disease

recommendation: It is recommended that patients with CHD and conﬁrmed pre-capillary PHc are counselled against pregnancy.
table_name: treatment of pulmonary arterial hypertension associated with congenital heart disease

recommendation: Risk assessment is recommended in all patients with PAH-CHD.d
table_name: treatment of pulmonary arterial hypertension associated with congenital heart disease

recommendation: In low- and intermediate-risk patients with repaired simple lesions and pre-capillary PH, initial oral combination therapy or sequential combination therapy is recommended and highrisk patients should be treated with initial combination therapy including parenteral prostanoids.e 63
table_name: treatment of pulmonary arterial hypertension associated with congenital heart disease

recommendation: In Eisenmenger patients with reduced exercise capacity (6MWT distance <450 m), a treatment strategy with initial endothelin receptor antagonist monotherapy should be considered followed by combination therapy if patients fail to improve.67
table_name: treatment of pulmonary arterial hypertension associated with congenital heart disease

recommendation: In patients with evidence of RV volume overloadc and no PAH (no non-invasive signs of PAP elevation or invasive conﬁrmation of PVR <3 WU in case of such signs) or LV disease, ASD closure is recommended regardless of symptoms.
table_name: intervention in atrial septal defect (native and residual)

recommendation: Device closure is recommended as the method of choice for secundum ASD closure when technically suitable.
table_name: intervention in atrial septal defect (native and residual)

recommendation: In elderly patients not suitable for device closure, it is recommended to carefully weigh the surgical risk against the potential beneﬁt of ASD closure.
table_name: intervention in atrial septal defect (native and residual)

recommendation: In patients with non-invasive signs of PAP elevation, invasive measurement of PVR is mandatory.
table_name: intervention in atrial septal defect (native and residual)

recommendation: In patients with LV disease, it is recommended to perform balloon testing and carefully weigh the beneﬁt of eliminating LR shunt against the potential negative impact of ASD closure on outcome due to an increase in ﬁlling pressure (taking closure, fenestrated closure, and no closure into consideration).
table_name: intervention in atrial septal defect (native and residual)

recommendation: In patients with suspicion of paradoxical embolism (exclusion of other causes), ASD closure should be considered regardless of size providing there is absence of PAH and LV disease.
table_name: intervention in atrial septal defect (native and residual)

recommendation: In patients with PVR 35 WU, ASD closure should be considered when signiﬁcant LR shunt is present (Qp:Qs >1.5).
table_name: intervention in atrial septal defect (native and residual)

recommendation: In patients with PVR >_5 WU, fenestrated ASD closure may be considered when PVR falls below 5 WU after targeted PAH treatment and signiﬁcant LR shunt is present (Qp:Qs >1.5).
table_name: intervention in atrial septal defect (native and residual)

recommendation: ASD closure is not recommended in patients with Eisenmenger physiology, patients with PAH and PVR >_5 WU despite targeted PAH treatment, or desaturation on exercise.d
table_name: intervention in atrial septal defect (native and residual)

recommendation: In patients with evidence of LV volume overloadc and no PAH (no non-invasive signs of PAP elevation or invasive conﬁrmation of PVR <3 WU in case of such signs), VSD closure is recommended regardless of symptoms.
table_name: intervention in ventricular septal defect (native and residual)

recommendation: In patients with no signiﬁcant LR shunt, but a history of repeated episodes of IE, VSD closure should be considered.
table_name: intervention in ventricular septal defect (native and residual)

recommendation: In patients with VSD-associated prolapse of an aortic valve cusp causing progressive AR, surgery should be considered.
table_name: intervention in ventricular septal defect (native and residual)

recommendation: In patients who have developed PAH with PVR 35 WU, VSD closure should be considered when there is still signiﬁcant LR shunt (Qp:Qs >1.5).
table_name: intervention in ventricular septal defect (native and residual)

recommendation: In patients who have developed PAH with PVR >_5 WU, VSD closure may be considered when there is still signiﬁcant LR shunt (Qp:Qs >1.5), but careful individual decision in expert centres is required.
table_name: intervention in ventricular septal defect (native and residual)

recommendation: VSD closure is not recommended in patients with Eisenmenger physiology and patients with severe PAH (PVR >_5 WU) presenting with desaturation on exercise.d
table_name: intervention in ventricular septal defect (native and residual)

recommendation: Complete AVSD Surgical repair is not recommended in patients with Eisenmenger physiology, and patients with PAH (PVR >_5 WU) presenting with desaturation on exercise.c

For recommendations on intervention see also recommendations for intervention in VSD (section 4.2). Partial AVSD (primum ASD) Surgical closure is recommended in patients with signiﬁcant RV volume overload and should only be performed by a congenital cardiac surgeon.

For further details see recommendations for intervention in ASD (section 4.1). AV valve regurgitation Valve surgery, preferably AV valve repair, is recommended in symptomatic patients with moderate to severe AV valve regurgitation and should be performed by a congenital cardiac surgeon.
In asymptomatic patients with severe leftsided AV valve regurgitation, valve surgery is recommended when LVESD >_45 mmd and/or LVEF <_60% provided other causes of LV dysfunction are excluded.

In asymptomatic patients with severe leftsided AV valve regurgitation, preserved LV function (LVESD <45 mmd and/or LVEF >60%), high likelihood of successful valve repair, and low surgical risk, intervention should be considered when atrial ﬁbrillation or systolic PAP >50 mmHg is present.

In patients with evidence of LV volume overloadc and no PAH (no non-invasive signs of PAP elevation or invasive conﬁrmation of PVR <3 WU in case of such signs), PDA closure is recommended regardless of symptoms.
Device closure is recommended as the method of choice when technically suitable.
In patients who have developed PAH with PVR 35 WU, PDA closure should be considered when there is still signiﬁcant LR shunt (Qp:Qs >1.5).
In patients who have developed PAH with PVR >_5 WU, PDA closure may be considered when there is still signiﬁcant LR shunt (Qp:Qs >1.5) but careful individual decision in expert centres is required.
PDA closure is not recommended in patients with Eisenmenger physiology and patients with lower limb desaturation on exercise.d
Symptomatic patients with aortic valve stenosis In symptomatic patients with severe high-gradient AS (mean gradient >_40 mmHg), intervention is recommended.
Intervention is indicated in symptomatic patients with severe low-ﬂow, low-gradient (mean gradient <40 mmHg) AS with reduced EF and evidence of ﬂow (contractile) reserve excluding pseudosevere AS.

Asymptomatic patients with severe aortic valve stenosis Intervention is indicated in asymptomatic patients with severe AS and an abnormal exercise test showing symptoms on exercise clearly related to AS.
Intervention is indicated in asymptomatic patients with severe AS and systolic LV dysfunction (LVEF <50%) not due to another cause.
Intervention should be considered in asymptomatic patients with severe AS when they present with a fall in blood pressure below baseline during exercise testing.

Intervention should be considered in asymptomatic patients with normal EF and none of the above-mentioned exercise test abnormalities if the surgical risk is low and one of the following ﬁndings is present: • Very severe AS deﬁned by a Vmax >5.5 m/s. • Severe valve calciﬁcation and a rate of Vmax progression >_0.3 m/s/year. • Markedly elevated BNP levels (>3-fold ageand sex-corrected normal range) conﬁrmed by repeated measurements without other explanation. • Severe PH (systolic PAP at rest >60 mmHg conﬁrmed by invasive measurement) without other explanation.

Concomitant aortic valve surgery at the time of other cardiac/ ascending aorta surgery Surgery is recommended when patients with severe AS undergo surgery of the ascending aorta or of another valve, or CABG.
Patients with moderate AS undergoing CABG surgery or surgery of the ascending aorta or another valve should be considered for additional valve replacement.
In symptomatic patients (spontaneous or on exercise test) with a mean Doppler gradient >_40 mmHgc or severe AR, surgery is recommended.

Asymptomatic patients should be considered for surgery when one or more of the following ﬁndings are present: • Mean gradient <40 mmHg but LVEF <50%. • AR is severe and LVESD >50 mm (or 25 mm/m2 BSA) and/or EF <50%d. • Mean Doppler gradient is >_40 mmHgc and marked LVH present. • Mean Doppler gradient is >_40 mmHgc and there is a fall in blood pressure below baseline on exercise.

Asymptomatic patients may be considered for surgery when one or more of the following ﬁndings are present: • Mean Doppler gradient is >_40 mmHg,c LV is normal (EF >50% and no LVH), exercise testing is normal, and surgical risk is low. • Progression of AR is documented and AR becomes more than mild (to prevent further progression).

Repair of coarctation or re-coarctation (surgically or catheter based) is indicated in hypertensive patientsc with an increased non-invasive gradient between upper and lower limbs conﬁrmed with invasive measurement (peak-topeak >_20 mmHg) with preference for catheter treatment (stenting), when technically feasible.
table_name: intervention in coarctation and re-coarctation of the aorta

recommendation: Catheter treatment (stenting) should be considered in hypertensive patientsc with >_50% narrowing relative to the aortic diameter at the diaphragm, even if the invasive peak-to-peak gradient is <20 mmHg, when technically feasible.
table_name: intervention in coarctation and re-coarctation of the aorta

recommendation: Catheter treatment (stenting) should be considered in normotensive patientsc with an increased non-invasive gradient conﬁrmed with invasive measurement (peak-to-peak >_20 mmHg), when technically feasible.
table_name: intervention in coarctation and re-coarctation of the aorta

recommendation: Catheter treatment (stenting) may be considered in normotensive patientsc with >_50% narrowing relative to the aortic diameter at the diaphragm, even if the invasive peak-to-peak gradient is <20 mmHg, when technically feasible.
table_name: intervention in coarctation and re-coarctation of the aorta

recommendation: Marfan syndrome and HTAD Aortic valve repair, using the reimplantation or remodelling with aortic annuloplasty technique, is recommended in young patients with Marfan syndrome or related HTAD with aortic root dilation and tricuspid aortic valves, when performed by experienced surgeons.
