recommendation: Interruption of anticoagulation When an urgent surgical intervention is required, it is recommended that NOAC therapy is immediately interrupted.
table_name: Recommendations for interruption and resumption of anticoagulants in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: Idarucizumab should be considered in patients on dabigatran and requiring urgent surgical intervention with intermediate to high bleeding risk.
table_name: Recommendations for interruption and resumption of anticoagulants in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: For interventions with a very high risk of bleeding, such as spinal or epidural anaesthesia, interruption of NOACs for up to ﬁve half-lives and re-initiation after 24 h should be considered.
table_name: Recommendations for interruption and resumption of anticoagulants in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: When speciﬁc reversal agents are unavailable, PCC or activated PCC should be considered for reversing NOAC effects.
table_name: Recommendations for interruption and resumption of anticoagulants in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: If an urgent surgical intervention is required, speciﬁc coagulation tests and assessment of NOAC plasma levels should be considered to interpret routine coagulation tests and waning of anticoagulant effect.
table_name: Recommendations for interruption and resumption of anticoagulants in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: Continuation of medication In minor bleeding risk surgery and other procedures where bleeding can be easily controlled, it is recommended to perform surgery without interruption of OAC therapy.240,296–
table_name: Recommendations for interruption and resumption of anticoagulants in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: LMWH is recommended, as an alternative to UFH, for bridging in patients with MHVs and high surgical risk.
table_name: Recommendations for interruption and resumption of anticoagulants in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: In patients using NOACs, it is recommended that minor bleeding risk procedures are performed at trough levels (typically 12–24 h after last intake).
table_name: Recommendations for interruption and resumption of anticoagulants in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: For patients with mechanical prosthetic heart valves undergoing NCS, bridging with UFH or LMWH should be considered if OAC interruption is needed and patients have: (i) mechanical AVR and any thromboembolic risk factor; (ii) old-generation mechanical AVR; or (iii) mechanical mitral or tricuspid valve replacement.
table_name: Recommendations for interruption and resumption of anticoagulants in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: Bridging of OAC therapy is not recommended in patients with low/moderate thrombotic risk undergoing NCS.290,292,293,306–
table_name: Recommendations for interruption and resumption of anticoagulants in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: Start/resumption of medication If bleeding risk with resumption of full-dose anticoagulation outweighs the risk of thromboembolic events, postponing therapeutic anticoagulation 48–72 h after the procedure may be considered, using post-operative thromboprophylaxis until resumption of full OAC dose is deemed safe.
table_name: Recommendations for interruption and resumption of anticoagulants in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: Use of reduced-dose NOAC to attenuate the risk of post-operative bleeding is not recommended.
table_name: Recommendations for interruption and resumption of anticoagulants in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: It is recommended that decisions about peri-operative thromboprophylaxis in NCS are based on individual and procedure-speciﬁc risk factors.

If thromboprophylaxis is deemed necessary, it is recommended to choose the type and duration of thromboprophylaxis (LMWH, NOAC, or fondaparinux) according to type of NCS, duration of immobilization, and patient-related factors.
In patients with a low bleeding risk, peri-operative thromboprophylaxis should be considered for a duration of up to 14 or 35 days, for total knee or hip arthroplasty, respectively.334–
NOACs in thromboprophylaxis dose may be considered as alternative treatments to LMWH after total knee and hip arthroplasty.
It is recommended to measure haemoglobin pre-operatively in patients scheduled for intermediate- to high-risk NCS.
table_name: Recommendations for intra- and post-operative complications associated with anaemia

recommendation: It is recommended to treat anaemia in advance of NCS, in order to reduce the need for RBC transfusion during NCS.
table_name: Recommendations for intra- and post-operative complications associated with anaemia

recommendation: The use of an algorithm to diagnose and treat anaemic patients before NCS should be considered.
table_name: Recommendations for intra- and post-operative complications associated with anaemia

recommendation: In patients undergoing surgery with expected blood loss of ≥500 mL, use of washed cell salvage is recommended.
table_name: Recommendations for intra- and post-operative complications associated with blood loss

recommendation: It is recommended to use point-of-care diagnostics for guidance of blood component therapy, when available.370,379–
table_name: Recommendations for intra- and post-operative complications associated with blood loss

recommendation: Use of closed-loop arterial blood sampling systems should be considered to avoid blood loss.
table_name: Recommendations for intra- and post-operative complications associated with blood loss

recommendation: Application of meticulous haemostasis should be considered a routine procedure.
table_name: Recommendations for intra- and post-operative complications associated with blood loss

recommendation: A feedback/monitoring programme or clinical decision support system should be considered to be assessed before blood transfusion.392–
table_name: Recommendations for intra- and post-operative complications associated with allogeneic blood transfusion

recommendation: Before allogenic blood transfusion, it should be considered to obtain an extensive consent about risks asssociated with transfusion.
table_name: Recommendations for intra- and post-operative complications associated with allogeneic blood transfusion

recommendation: Patients with CCS If PCI is indicated before NCS, the use of new-generation DES is recommended over BMS and balloon angioplasty.
table_name: Recommendations for the timing of non-cardiac surgery and revascularization in patients with known coronary artery disease

recommendation: Pre-operative evaluation of patients with an indication for PCI by an expert team (surgeon and cardiologist) should be considered before elective NCS.
table_name: Recommendations for the timing of non-cardiac surgery and revascularization in patients with known coronary artery disease

recommendation: Myocardial revascularization before high-risk elective NCS may be considered, depending on the amount of ischaemic myocardium, refractory symptoms, and ﬁndings at coronary angiography (as in the case of left main disease).
table_name: Recommendations for the timing of non-cardiac surgery and revascularization in patients with known coronary artery disease

recommendation: Routine myocardial revascularization before lowand intermediate-risk NCS in patients with CCS is not recommended.
table_name: Recommendations for the timing of non-cardiac surgery and revascularization in patients with known coronary artery disease

recommendation: Patients with ACS If NCS can safely be postponed (e.g. at least 3 months), it is recommended that patients with ACS being scheduled for NCS undergo diagnostic and therapeutic interventions as recommended for ACS patients in general.
table_name: Recommendations for the timing of non-cardiac surgery and revascularization in patients with known coronary artery disease

recommendation: In the unlikely combination of a life-threatening clinical condition requiring urgent NCS, and NSTE-ACS with an indication for revascularization, the priorities for surgery on a case-by-case basis should be considered by the expert team.
table_name: Recommendations for the timing of non-cardiac surgery and revascularization in patients with known coronary artery disease

recommendation: In patients with suspected or known HF scheduled for high-risk NCS, it is recommended to evaluate LV function with echocardiography and measurement of NT-proBNP/BNP levels, unless this has recently been performed.
table_name: Recommendations for management of heart failure in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: It is recommended that patients with HF undergoing NCS receive optimal medical treatment according to current ESC guidelines.
table_name: Recommendations for management of heart failure in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: In patients with HF undergoing NCS, it is recommended to regularly assess volume status and signs of organ perfusion.
table_name: Recommendations for management of heart failure in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: A multidisciplinary team including VAD specialists is recommended for peri-operative management of patients with HF receiving mechanical circulatory support.
table_name: Recommendations for management of heart failure in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: Clinical and echocardiographic evaluation (if not recently performed) is recommended in all patients with known or suspected VHD who are scheduled for elective intermediate- or high-risk NCS.
table_name: Recommendations for management of valvular heart disease in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: Aortic valve stenosis AVR (SAVR or TAVI) is recommended in symptomatic patients with severe AS who are scheduled for elective intermediate- or high-risk NCS.
table_name: Recommendations for management of valvular heart disease in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: In patients with severe symptomatic AS in need of time-sensitive NCS or in whom the TAVI and SAVR are unfeasible, BAV may be considered before NCS as a bridge to deﬁnitive aortic valve repair.
table_name: Recommendations for management of valvular heart disease in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: Aortic valve regurgitation In patients with symptomatic severe AR or asymptomatic severe AR and LVESD .50 mm or LVESDi (LVESD/BSA) .25 mm/m2 (in patients with small body size) or resting LVEF ≤50%, valve surgery is recommended prior to elective intermediate- or high-risk NCS.
table_name: Recommendations for management of valvular heart disease in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: Mitral valve stenosis In patients with moderate-to-severe rheumatic MS and symptoms or SPAP .50 mmHg, valve intervention (PMC or surgery) is recommended before elective intermediate- or high-risk NCS.
table_name: Recommendations for management of valvular heart disease in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: Mitral valve regurgitation In patients with symptomatic severe primary MR or asymptomatic severe primary MR with LV dysfunction (LVESD ≥40 mm and/or LVEF ≤60%), valve intervention (surgical or transcatheter) should be considered prior to intermediate- or high-risk NCS, if time allows.
table_name: Recommendations for management of valvular heart disease in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: In patients with severe secondary MR who remain symptomatic despite guideline-directed medical therapy (including CRT if indicated), valve intervention (transcatheter or surgical) should be considered before NCS, in eligible patients with an acceptable procedural risk.
table_name: Recommendations for management of valvular heart disease in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: Supraventricular arrhythmias In patients with SVT controlled by medication, it is recommended that AADs are
table_name: Recommendations for management of known or newly diagnosed arrhythmias

recommendation: Ablation should be considered in symptomatic patients with recurrent or persistent SVT, despite treatment, prior to high-risk, non-urgent NCS.437–
table_name: Recommendations for management of known or newly diagnosed arrhythmias

recommendation: AF with haemodynamic instability in patients undergoing NCS In AF patients with acute or worsening haemodynamic instability undergoing NCS, emergency electrical cardioversion is recommended.
table_name: Recommendations for management of known or newly diagnosed arrhythmias

recommendation: In AF patients with haemodynamic instability, amiodarone may be considered for acute control of heart rate.
table_name: Recommendations for management of known or newly diagnosed arrhythmias

recommendation: It is not recommended to initiate treatment of asymptomatic PVC during NCS.
table_name: Recommendations for management of known or newly diagnosed arrhythmias

recommendation: If indications for pacing exist according to the surgery should be deferred and implantation of a permanent pacemaker should be considered.
table_name: Recommendations for management of bradyarrhythmia and patients carrying cardiac implantable devices

recommendation: It is recommended that patients with temporarily deactivated ICDs have continuous ECG monitoring, and during the peri-operative period are accompanied by personnel skilled in early detection and treatment of arrhythmias. In high-risk patients (e.g. pacemaker-dependant or ICD patients), or if access to the torso will be difﬁcult during the procedure, it is recommended to place transcutaneous pacing/deﬁbrillation pads prior to NCS.
table_name: Recommendations for management of bradyarrhythmia and patients carrying cardiac implantable devices

recommendation: It is recommended that all patients with CIEDs that are reprogrammed before surgery have a re-check and necessary reprogramming as soon as possible after the procedure.
table_name: Recommendations for management of bradyarrhythmia and patients carrying cardiac implantable devices

recommendation: In patients with ACHD, a consultation with an ACHD specialist is recommended before intermediate- or high-risk surgery.
table_name: Recommendations for management of patients with adult congenital heart disease undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: In patients with ACHD, it is recommended that intermediate- and high-risk elective surgery is performed in a centre with experience in the care of ACHD patients.
table_name: Recommendations for management of patients with adult congenital heart disease undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: In patients with acute pericarditis, deferring elective NCS until complete resolution of the underlying process should be considered.
Avoiding elective NCS procedures under general anaesthesia until colchicine or the immunosuppressive treatment course for pericardial disease is completed may be considered.
It is recommended to continue chronic therapy for PAH in the peri-operative phase of NCS.
table_name: Recommendations for patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: It is recommended that haemodynamic monitoring of patients with severe PAH continues for at least 24 h in the post-operative period.
table_name: Recommendations for patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: In the case of progression of right HF in the post-operative period in patients with PAH, it is recommended that the diuretic dose be optimized and, if necessary, i.v. prostacyclin analogues be initiated under the guidance of a physician experienced in the management of PAH.
table_name: Recommendations for patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: Inodilator drugs (dobutamine, milrinone, levosimendan), which increase cardiac output and lower pulmonary vascular resistance, should be considered peri-operatively according to the haemodynamic status of the patient.
table_name: Recommendations for patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: In patients with chronic hypertension undergoing elective NCS, it is recommended to avoid large peri-operative ﬂuctuations in blood pressure, particularly hypotension, during the peri-operative period.
table_name: Recommendations for pre-operative management of hypertension

recommendation: It is recommended to perform pre-operative screening for hypertension-mediated organ damage and CV risk factors in newly diagnosed hypertensive patients who are scheduled for elective high-risk NCS.
table_name: Recommendations for pre-operative management of hypertension

recommendation: It is not recommended to defer NCS in patients with stage 1 or 2 hypertension.
table_name: Recommendations for pre-operative management of hypertension

recommendation: In patients with poor functional capacity or signiﬁcant risk factors or symptoms (such as moderate-to-severe angina pectoris, decompensated HF, valvular disease, and signiﬁcant arrhythmia), referral for cardiac work-up and optimization is recommended prior to elective surgery for PAD or AAA.
table_name: Recommendations for management of patients with peripheral artery disease and/or abdominal aortic aneurysm undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: Routine referral for cardiac work-up, coronary angiography, or CPET prior to elective surgery for PAD or AAA is not recommended.
table_name: Recommendations for management of patients with peripheral artery disease and/or abdominal aortic aneurysm undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: Pre-operative carotid artery and cerebral imaging is recommended in patients with a history of TIA or stroke in the previous 6 months and who have not undergone ipsilateral revascularization.
table_name: Recommendations for management of patients with suspected or established carotid artery disease undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: For patients with carotid artery disease undergoing NCS, the same indications for carotid revascularization should be considered as for other patients with carotid stenosis.
table_name: Recommendations for management of patients with suspected or established carotid artery disease undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: Pre-operative carotid artery imaging is not recommended routinely in patients undergoing NCS.
table_name: Recommendations for management of patients with suspected or established carotid artery disease undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: In patients with renal disease requiring peri-operative contrast-enhanced radiography, balanced hydration with i.v. isotonic ﬂuids, the use of a minimal volume of contrast media, and the use of low-osmolar or iso-osmolar contrast media should be considered.547,553–
table_name: Recommendations for management of patients with renal disease undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: In patients with known risk factors (age .65 years, BMI .30 kg/m2, diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidaemia, CV disease, or smoking) undergoing intermediate- or high-risk NCS, it is recommended to screen for pre-operative renal disease by measuring serum creatinine and GFR.
table_name: Recommendations for management of patients with renal disease undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: If a cystatin C measurement assay is available, cystatin C measurement should be considered in patients with impaired eGFR (,45–59 mL/min/ 1.73 m2) to conﬁrm kidney disease.
table_name: Recommendations for management of patients with renal disease undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: It is recommended to assess cardiorespiratory ﬁtness to estimate peri-operative CV risk in obese patients, with particular attention to those undergoing intermediate- and high-risk NCS.
table_name: Recommendations for management of patients with obesity undergoing noncardiac surgery

recommendation: In patients at high risk of obesity hypoventilation syndrome, additional specialist investigation before major elective NCS should be considered.
table_name: Recommendations for management of patients with obesity undergoing noncardiac surgery

recommendation: In patients with diabetes or disturbed glucose metabolism, a pre-operative HbA1c test is recommended, if this measurement has been not performed in the previous 3 months. In case of HbA1c ≥8.5% (≥69 mmol/mol), elective NCS should be postponed, if safe and practical.578–
table_name: Recommendations for management of patients with diabetes mellitus undergoing non-cardiac surgery

recommendation: In order to preserve optimal CV stability, it is recommended to apply goal-directed haemodynamic therapy in patients undergoing high-risk NCS.614–
table_name: Recommendations for peri-operative monitoring and anaesthesia

recommendation: It is recommended to avoid post-operative acute pain.
table_name: Recommendations for peri-operative monitoring and anaesthesia

recommendation: In order to minimize the risk of post-operative organ dysfunction, it is recommended to avoid an intra-operative mean arterial pressure decrease of .20% from baseline values or ,60–70 mmHg for ≥10 min.214,600–
table_name: Recommendations for peri-operative monitoring and anaesthesia

recommendation: Non-aspirin NSAIDs are not recommended as ﬁrst-line analgesics in patients with established or high risk of CVD.
table_name: Recommendations for peri-operative monitoring and anaesthesia

recommendation: It is recommended to have high awareness of peri-operative CV complications, combined with surveillance for PMI in patients undergoing intermediate- or high-risk NCS.41,101,109– 111,118,413,636–
Systematic PMI work-up is recommended to identify the underlying pathophysiology and deﬁne therapy.41,101,109–111,118,413,636–

It is recommended to treat post-operative STEMI, NSTE-ACS, acute HF, and tachyarrhythmias in accordance with guidelines for the non-surgical setting, after interdisciplinary discussion with the surgeon about bleeding risk.

In patients with post-operative PE of high or intermediate clinical probability, initiation of anticoagulation is recommended without delay, while diagnostic work-up is in progress, if bleeding risk is low.
Post-operative oral anticoagulation for PE is recommended to be administered for a period of at least 3 months.
In patients with a post-operative indication for OAC, NOAC is generally recommended over VKA.

In patients with post-operative AF after NCS, long-term OAC therapy should be considered in all patients at risk of stroke, considering the anticipated net clinical beneﬁt of OAC therapy, and informed patient preferences.
In patients with MINS and at low risk of bleeding, treatment with dabigatran 110 mg orally b.i.d. may be considered from ≏1 week after NCS.
Right heart catheterization It is recommended that RHC is performed to conﬁrm the diagnosis of PH (especially PAH or CTEPH) and to support treatment decisions
table_name: Recommendations for right heart catheterization and vasoreactivity testing

recommendation: In patients with suspected or known PH, it is recommended that RHC is performed in experienced centres
table_name: Recommendations for right heart catheterization and vasoreactivity testing

recommendation: It is recommended that RHC comprises a complete set of haemodynamics and is performed following standardized protocols
table_name: Recommendations for right heart catheterization and vasoreactivity testing

recommendation: Vasoreactivity testing Vasoreactivity testing is recommended in patients with I/H/DPAH to detect those who can be treated with high doses of a CCB
table_name: Recommendations for right heart catheterization and vasoreactivity testing

recommendation: It is recommended that vasoreactivity testing is performed at PH centres
table_name: Recommendations for right heart catheterization and vasoreactivity testing

recommendation: It is recommended to consider a positive response to vasoreactivity testing by a reduction in mPAP ≥10 mmHg to reach an absolute value of mPAP ≤40 mmHg with an increased or unchanged COc
table_name: Recommendations for right heart catheterization and vasoreactivity testing

recommendation: Inhaled nitric oxide, inhaled iloprost, or i.v. epoprostenol are recommended for performing vasoreactivity testing129–
table_name: Recommendations for right heart catheterization and vasoreactivity testing

recommendation: Vasoreactivity testing, for identifying candidates for CCB therapy, is not recommended in patients with PAH other than I/H/DPAH, and in PH groups 2, 3, 4, and
table_name: Recommendations for right heart catheterization and vasoreactivity testing

recommendation: Recommendation Echocardiography Echocardiography is recommended as the ﬁrst-line, non-invasive, diagnostic investigation in suspected PH
It is recommended to assign an echocardiographic probability of PH, based on an abnormal TRV and the presence of other echocardiographic signs suggestive of PH (see Table 10)
It is recommended to maintain the current threshold for TRV (.2.8 m/s) for echocardiographic probability of PH according to the updated haemodynamic deﬁnition
Based on the probability of PH by echocardiography, further testing should be considered in the clinical context (i.e. symptoms and risk factors or associated conditions for PAH/ CTEPH)
In symptomatic patients with intermediate echocardiographic probability of PH, CPET may be considered to further determine the likelihood of PH
CT pulmonary angiography is recommended in the work-up of patients with suspected CTEPH
Routine biochemistry, haematology, immunology, HIV testing, and thyroid function tests are recommended in all patients with PAH, to identify associated conditions
Abdominal ultrasound is recommended for the screening of portal hypertension
Chest CT should be considered in all patients with PH
Digital subtraction angiography should be considered in the work-up of patients with CTEPH
Other diagnostic tests Pulmonary function tests with DLCO are recommended in the initial evaluation of patients with PH
Open or thoracoscopic lung biopsy is not recommended in patients with PAH
Systemic sclerosis In patients with SSc, an annual evaluation of the risk of having PAH is recommended
table_name: Recommendations for screening and improved detection of pulmonary arterial hypertension and chronic thrombo-embolic pulmonary hypertension

recommendation: In patients with SSc, where breathlessness remains unexplained following non-invasive assessment, RHC is recommended to exclude PAH185–
table_name: Recommendations for screening and improved detection of pulmonary arterial hypertension and chronic thrombo-embolic pulmonary hypertension

recommendation: Assessing the risk of having PAH based on an evaluation of breathlessness, in combination with echocardiogram or PFTs and BNP/NT-proBNP, should be considered in patients with SSc
table_name: Recommendations for screening and improved detection of pulmonary arterial hypertension and chronic thrombo-embolic pulmonary hypertension

recommendation: Policies to evaluate the risk of having PAH should be considered in hospitals managing patients with SSc
table_name: Recommendations for screening and improved detection of pulmonary arterial hypertension and chronic thrombo-embolic pulmonary hypertension

recommendation: In symptomatic patients with SSc, exercise echocardiography or CPET, or CMR may be considered to aid decisions to perform RHC
table_name: Recommendations for screening and improved detection of pulmonary arterial hypertension and chronic thrombo-embolic pulmonary hypertension

recommendation: In patients with CTD with overlap features of SSc, an annual evaluation of the risk of PAH may be considered
table_name: Recommendations for screening and improved detection of pulmonary arterial hypertension and chronic thrombo-embolic pulmonary hypertension

recommendation: CTEPH/CTEPD In patients with persistent or new-onset dyspnoea or exercise limitation following PE, further diagnostic evaluation to assess for CTEPH/ CTEPD is recommended
table_name: Recommendations for screening and improved detection of pulmonary arterial hypertension and chronic thrombo-embolic pulmonary hypertension

recommendation: For symptomatic patients with mismatched perfusion lung defects beyond 3 months of anticoagulation for acute PE, referral to a PH/ CTEPH centre is recommended after considering the results of echocardiography, BNP/ NT-proBNP, and/or CPET
table_name: Recommendations for screening and improved detection of pulmonary arterial hypertension and chronic thrombo-embolic pulmonary hypertension

recommendation: Other Counselling regarding the risk of PAH and annual screening are recommended in individuals who test positive for PAH-causing mutations and in ﬁrst-degree relatives of patients with HPAH
table_name: Recommendations for screening and improved detection of pulmonary arterial hypertension and chronic thrombo-embolic pulmonary hypertension

recommendation: In patients referred for liver transplantation, echocardiography is recommended as a screening test for PH
table_name: Recommendations for screening and improved detection of pulmonary arterial hypertension and chronic thrombo-embolic pulmonary hypertension

recommendation: Further tests (echocardiography, BNP/ NT-proBNP, PFTs, and/or CPET) should be considered in symptomatic patients with CTD, portal hypertension, or HIV to screen for PAH
table_name: Recommendations for screening and improved detection of pulmonary arterial hypertension and chronic thrombo-embolic pulmonary hypertension

recommendation: It is recommended to evaluate disease severity in patients with PAH with a panel of data derived from clinical assessment, exercise tests, biochemical markers, echocardiography, and haemodynamic evaluations
table_name: Recommendations for evaluating the disease severity and risk of death in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension

recommendation: Achieving and maintaining a low-risk proﬁle on optimized medical therapy is recommended as a treatment goal in patients with PAH
table_name: Recommendations for evaluating the disease severity and risk of death in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension

recommendation: For risk stratiﬁcation at the time of diagnosis, the use of a three-strata model (low, intermediate, and high risk) is recommended, taking into account all available data, including haemodynamics
table_name: Recommendations for evaluating the disease severity and risk of death in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension

recommendation: For risk stratiﬁcation during follow-up, the use of a four-strata model (low, intermediate–low, intermediate–high, and high risk) based on WHO-FC, 6MWD, and BNP/NT-proBNP is recommended, with additional variables taken into account as necessary
table_name: Recommendations for evaluating the disease severity and risk of death in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension

recommendation: In some PAH aetiologies and patients with comorbidities, optimization of therapy should be considered on an individual basis, while acknowledging that a low-risk proﬁle is not always achievable
table_name: Recommendations for evaluating the disease severity and risk of death in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension

recommendation: General measures Supervised exercise training is recommended in patients with PAH under medical therapy
table_name: Recommendations for general measures and special circumstances

recommendation: Immunization of patients with PAH against SARS-CoV-2, inﬂuenza, and Streptococcus pneumoniae is recommended
table_name: Recommendations for general measures and special circumstances

recommendation: Diuretic treatment is recommended in patients with PAH with signs of RV failure and ﬂuid retention
table_name: Recommendations for general measures and special circumstances

recommendation: Long-term oxygen therapy is recommended in patients with PAH whose arterial blood oxygen pressure is ,8 kPa (60 mmHg)c
table_name: Recommendations for general measures and special circumstances

recommendation: In the presence of iron-deﬁciency anaemia, correction of iron status is recommended in patients with PAH
table_name: Recommendations for general measures and special circumstances

recommendation: In the absence of anaemia, iron repletion may be considered in patients with PAH with iron deﬁciency
table_name: Recommendations for general measures and special circumstances

recommendation: Anticoagulation is not generally recommended in patients with PAH but may be considered on an individual basis
table_name: Recommendations for general measures and special circumstances

recommendation: The use of ACEis, ARBs, ARNIs, SGLT-2is, beta-blockers, or ivabradine is not recommended in patients with PAH unless required by comorbidities (i.e. high blood pressure, coronary artery disease, left HF, or arrhythmias)
table_name: Recommendations for general measures and special circumstances

recommendation: Special circumstances In-ﬂight oxygen administration is recommended for patients using oxygen or whose arterial blood oxygen pressure is ,8 kPa (60 mmHg) at sea level
table_name: Recommendations for general measures and special circumstances

recommendation: For interventions requiring anaesthesia, multidisciplinary consultation at a PH centre to assess risk and beneﬁt should be considered
table_name: Recommendations for general measures and special circumstances

recommendation: It is recommended that women of childbearing potential with PAH are counselled at the time of diagnosis about the risks and uncertainties associated with becoming pregnant; this should include advice against becoming pregnant, and referral for psychological support where needed
table_name: Recommendations for women of childbearing potential

recommendation: It is recommended that women with PAH who consider pregnancy or who become pregnant receive prompt counselling in an experienced PH centre, to facilitate genetic counselling and shared decision-making, and to provide psychological support to the patients and their families where needed
table_name: Recommendations for women of childbearing potential

recommendation: For women with PAH having a termination of pregnancy, it is recommended that this be performed in PH centres, with psychological support provided to the patients and their families
table_name: Recommendations for women of childbearing potential

recommendation: For women with PAH who desire to have children, where available, adoption and surrogacy with preconception genetic counselling may be considered
table_name: Recommendations for women of childbearing potential

recommendation: As teratogenic potential has been reported in pre-clinical models for endothelin receptor antagonists and riociguat, these drugs are not recommended during pregnancy
table_name: Recommendations for women of childbearing potential

recommendation: High doses of CCBs are recommended in patients with IPAH, HPAH, or DPAH who are responders to acute vasoreactivity testing
table_name: Recommendations for the treatment of vasoreactive patients with idiopathic, heritable, or drug-associated pulmonary arterial hypertension

recommendation: Close follow-up with complete reassessment after 3–4 months of therapy (including RHC) is recommended in patients with IPAH, HPAH, or DPAH treated with high doses of CCBs
table_name: Recommendations for the treatment of vasoreactive patients with idiopathic, heritable, or drug-associated pulmonary arterial hypertension

recommendation: Continuing high doses of CCBs is recommended in patients with IPAH, HPAH, or DPAH in WHO-FC I or II with marked haemodynamic improvement (mPAP ,30 mmHg and PVR ,4 WU)
table_name: Recommendations for the treatment of vasoreactive patients with idiopathic, heritable, or drug-associated pulmonary arterial hypertension

recommendation: Initiating PAH therapy is recommended in patients who remain in WHO-FC III or IV or those without marked haemodynamic improvement after high doses of CCBs
table_name: Recommendations for the treatment of vasoreactive patients with idiopathic, heritable, or drug-associated pulmonary arterial hypertension

recommendation: In patients with a positive vasoreactivity test but insufﬁcient long-term response to CCBs who require additional PAH therapy, continuation of CCB therapy should be considered
table_name: Recommendations for the treatment of vasoreactive patients with idiopathic, heritable, or drug-associated pulmonary arterial hypertension

recommendation: CCBs are not recommended in patients without a vasoreactivity study or non-responders, unless prescribed for other indications (e.g. Raynaud’s phenomenon)
table_name: Recommendations for the treatment of vasoreactive patients with idiopathic, heritable, or drug-associated pulmonary arterial hypertension

recommendation: Initial combination therapy with ambrisentan and tadalaﬁl is recommended
table_name: Recommendations for initial oral drug combination therapy for patients with idiopathic, heritable, or drug-associated pulmonary arterial hypertension without cardiopulmonary comorbidities

recommendation: Initial combination therapy with macitentan and tadalaﬁl is recommended
table_name: Recommendations for initial oral drug combination therapy for patients with idiopathic, heritable, or drug-associated pulmonary arterial hypertension without cardiopulmonary comorbidities

recommendation: Initial combination therapy with other ERAs and PDE5is should be considered
table_name: Recommendations for initial oral drug combination therapy for patients with idiopathic, heritable, or drug-associated pulmonary arterial hypertension without cardiopulmonary comorbidities

recommendation: Initial combination therapy with macitentan, tadalaﬁl, and selexipag is not recommended
table_name: Recommendations for initial oral drug combination therapy for patients with idiopathic, heritable, or drug-associated pulmonary arterial hypertension without cardiopulmonary comorbidities

recommendation: General recommendation for sequential combination therapy It is recommended to base treatment escalations on risk assessment and general treatment strategies (see Figure 9)
table_name: Recommendations for sequential drug combination therapy for patients with idiopathic, heritable, or drug-associated pulmonary arterial hypertension

recommendation: Evidence from studies with a composite morbidity/mortality endpoint as the primary outcome measure The addition of macitentan to PDE5is or oral/ inhaled prostacyclin analogues is recommended to reduce the risk of morbidity/mortality events
table_name: Recommendations for sequential drug combination therapy for patients with idiopathic, heritable, or drug-associated pulmonary arterial hypertension

recommendation: The addition of selexipag to ERAsc and/or PDE5is is recommended to reduce the risk of morbidity/ mortality events
table_name: Recommendations for sequential drug combination therapy for patients with idiopathic, heritable, or drug-associated pulmonary arterial hypertension

recommendation: The addition of oral treprostinil to ERA or PDE5i/ riociguat monotherapy is recommended to reduce the risk of morbidity/mortality events
table_name: Recommendations for sequential drug combination therapy for patients with idiopathic, heritable, or drug-associated pulmonary arterial hypertension

recommendation: The addition of bosentan to sildenaﬁl is not recommended to reduce the risk of morbidity/ mortality events419a
table_name: Recommendations for sequential drug combination therapy for patients with idiopathic, heritable, or drug-associated pulmonary arterial hypertension

recommendation: Evidence from studies with change in 6MWD as the primary outcome measure The addition of sildenaﬁl to epoprostenol is recommended to improve exercise capacity
table_name: Recommendations for sequential drug combination therapy for patients with idiopathic, heritable, or drug-associated pulmonary arterial hypertension

recommendation: The addition of inhaled treprostinil to sildenaﬁl or bosentan monotherapy should be considered to improve exercise capacity
table_name: Recommendations for sequential drug combination therapy for patients with idiopathic, heritable, or drug-associated pulmonary arterial hypertension

recommendation: The addition of riociguat to bosentan should be considered to improve exercise capacity
table_name: Recommendations for sequential drug combination therapy for patients with idiopathic, heritable, or drug-associated pulmonary arterial hypertension

recommendation: The addition of inhaled iloprost to bosentan may be considered to improve exercise capacity
table_name: Recommendations for sequential drug combination therapy for patients with idiopathic, heritable, or drug-associated pulmonary arterial hypertension

recommendation: The addition of ambrisentan to sildenaﬁl may be considered to improve exercise capacity
table_name: Recommendations for sequential drug combination therapy for patients with idiopathic, heritable, or drug-associated pulmonary arterial hypertension

recommendation: The addition of bosentan to sildenaﬁl may be considered to improve exercise capacity
table_name: Recommendations for sequential drug combination therapy for patients with idiopathic, heritable, or drug-associated pulmonary arterial hypertension

recommendation: The addition of sildenaﬁl to bosentan may be considered to improve exercise capacity444–
table_name: Recommendations for sequential drug combination therapy for patients with idiopathic, heritable, or drug-associated pulmonary arterial hypertension

recommendation: Other sequential double- or triple-combination therapies may be considered to improve exercise capacity and/or alleviate PH symptoms
table_name: Recommendations for sequential drug combination therapy for patients with idiopathic, heritable, or drug-associated pulmonary arterial hypertension

recommendation: Evidence from studies with safety of combination therapy as the primary outcome measure Combining riociguat and PDE5is is not recommendedd
table_name: Recommendations for sequential drug combination therapy for patients with idiopathic, heritable, or drug-associated pulmonary arterial hypertension

recommendation: Classb Levelc Recommendations for initial therapy In patients with IPAH/HPAH/DPAH and cardiopulmonary comorbidities, initial monotherapy with a PDE5i or an ERA should be considered
table_name: Recommendations for the treatment of non-vasoreactive patients with idiopathic, heritable, or drug-associated pulmonary arterial hypertension who present with cardiopulmonary comorbiditiesa

recommendation: Recommendations for treatment decisions during follow-up In patients with IPAH/HPAH/DPAH with cardiopulmonary comorbidities who present at intermediate or high risk of death while receiving PDE5i or ERA monotherapy, additional PAH medication may be considered on an individual basis
table_name: Recommendations for the treatment of non-vasoreactive patients with idiopathic, heritable, or drug-associated pulmonary arterial hypertension who present with cardiopulmonary comorbiditiesa

recommendation: When managing patients with right HF in the ICU, it is recommended to involve physicians with expertise, treat causative factors, and use supportive measures, including inotropes and vasopressors, ﬂuid management, and PAH drugs, as appropriate
table_name: Recommendations for intensive care management for pulmonary arterial hypertension

recommendation: Mechanical circulatory support may be an option for selected patients as a bridge to transplantation or recovery, and interhospital transfer should be considered if such resources are unavailable on site
table_name: Recommendations for intensive care management for pulmonary arterial hypertension

recommendation: It is recommended that potentially eligible candidates are referred for LTx evaluation when they have an inadequate response to oral combination therapy, indicated by an intermediate– high or high risk or by a REVEAL risk score .

It is recommended to list patients for LTx who present with a high risk of death or with a REVEAL risk score ≥10 despite receiving optimized medical therapy including s.c. or i.v. prostacyclin analogues
It is recommended to make a diagnosis of drug- or toxin-associated PAH in patients who had relevant exposure and in whom other causes of PH have been excluded
table_name: Recommendations for pulmonary arterial hypertension associated with drugs or toxins

recommendation: In patients with suspected drug- or toxin-associated PAH, it is recommended to immediately discontinue the causative agent whenever possible
table_name: Recommendations for pulmonary arterial hypertension associated with drugs or toxins

recommendation: Patients with low-risk PAH should be re-evaluated 3–4 months after discontinuing the suspected drug or toxin, and PAH therapy may be considered when the haemodynamics have not normalized
table_name: Recommendations for pulmonary arterial hypertension associated with drugs or toxins

recommendation: In patients with PAH associated with CTD, treatment of the underlying condition according to current guidelines is recommended
table_name: Recommendations for pulmonary arterial hypertension associated with connective tissue disease

recommendation: In patients with PAH associated with HIV infection, antiretroviral treatment according to current guidelines is recommended
table_name: Recommendations for pulmonary arterial hypertension associated with human immunodeﬁciency virus infection

recommendation: In patients with PAH associated with HIV infection, initial monotherapy should be considered, followed by sequential combination if necessary, taking into consideration comorbidities and drug–drug interactions
table_name: Recommendations for pulmonary arterial hypertension associated with human immunodeﬁciency virus infection

recommendation: Echocardiography is recommended in patients with liver disease or portal hypertension with signs or symptoms suggestive of PH, and as a screening tool in patients evaluated for liver transplantation or transjugular portosystemic shunt
table_name: Recommendations for pulmonary arterial hypertension associated with portal hypertension

recommendation: It is recommended that patients with PAH associated with portal hypertension are referred to centres with expertise in managing both conditions
table_name: Recommendations for pulmonary arterial hypertension associated with portal hypertension

recommendation: In patients with PAH associated with portal hypertension, initial monotherapy should be considered, followed by sequential combination if necessary, taking into consideration the underlying liver disease and indication for liver transplantation
table_name: Recommendations for pulmonary arterial hypertension associated with portal hypertension

recommendation: Liver transplantation should be considered on an individual basis in patients with PAH associated with portal hypertension, as long as PVR is normal or near normal with PAH therapy
table_name: Recommendations for pulmonary arterial hypertension associated with portal hypertension

recommendation: Drugs approved for PAH are not recommended for patients with portal hypertension and unclassiﬁed PH (i.e. elevated mPAP, high CO, and a normal PVR)
table_name: Recommendations for pulmonary arterial hypertension associated with portal hypertension

recommendation: ﬂow ratio .1.5:1 based on calculated pulmonary vascular resistance In patients with an ASD, VSD, or PDA and a PVR ,3 WU, shunt closure is recommended
table_name: Recommendations for shunt closure in patients with pulmonary–systemic

recommendation: In patients with an ASD, VSD, or PDA and a PVR of 3–5 WU, shunt closure should be considered
table_name: Recommendations for shunt closure in patients with pulmonary–systemic

recommendation: In patients with an ASD and a PVR .5 WU that declines to ,5 WU with PAH treatment, shunt closure may be considered
table_name: Recommendations for shunt closure in patients with pulmonary–systemic

recommendation: In patients with a VSD or PDA and a PVR .5 WU, shunt closure may be considered after careful evaluation in specialized centres
table_name: Recommendations for shunt closure in patients with pulmonary–systemic

recommendation: In patients with an ASD and a PVR .5 WU despite PAH treatment, shunt closure is not recommended
table_name: Recommendations for shunt closure in patients with pulmonary–systemic

recommendation: Risk assessment Risk assessment is recommended for patients with persistent PAH after defect closure
table_name: Recommendations for pulmonary arterial hypertension associated with adult congenital heart disease

recommendation: Risk assessment should be considered in patients with Eisenmenger syndrome
table_name: Recommendations for pulmonary arterial hypertension associated with adult congenital heart disease

recommendation: Treatment Bosentan is recommended in symptomatic patients with Eisenmenger syndrome to improve exercise capacity
table_name: Recommendations for pulmonary arterial hypertension associated with adult congenital heart disease

recommendation: In patients with Eisenmenger syndrome, the use of supplemental oxygen therapy should be considered in cases where it consistently increases arterial oxygen saturation and reduces symptoms
table_name: Recommendations for pulmonary arterial hypertension associated with adult congenital heart disease

recommendation: Supplemental iron treatment should be considered in patients with iron deﬁciency
table_name: Recommendations for pulmonary arterial hypertension associated with adult congenital heart disease

recommendation: In patients with adult CHD, including Eisenmenger syndrome, other ERAs, PDE5is, riociguat, prostacyclin analogues, and prostacyclin receptor agonists should be considered
table_name: Recommendations for pulmonary arterial hypertension associated with adult congenital heart disease

recommendation: In the absence of signiﬁcant haemoptysis, oral anticoagulant treatment may be considered in patients with Eisenmenger syndrome with pulmonary artery thrombosis
table_name: Recommendations for pulmonary arterial hypertension associated with adult congenital heart disease

recommendation: In women with Eisenmenger syndrome, pregnancy is not recommended
table_name: Recommendations for pulmonary arterial hypertension associated with adult congenital heart disease

recommendation: In patients with Eisenmenger syndrome, routine phlebotomy to lower elevated haematocrit is not recommended
table_name: Recommendations for pulmonary arterial hypertension associated with adult congenital heart disease

recommendation: capillary involvement A combination of clinical and radiological ﬁndings, ABG, PFTs, and genetic testing is recommended to diagnose PAH with signs of venous and/or capillary involvement (PVOD/PCH)
table_name: Recommendations for pulmonary arterial hypertension with signs of venous/

recommendation: Identiﬁcation of biallelic EIF2AK4 mutations is recommended to conﬁrm a diagnosis of heritable PVOD/PCH
table_name: Recommendations for pulmonary arterial hypertension with signs of venous/

recommendation: Referral of eligible patients with PVOD/PCH to a transplant centre for evaluation is recommended as soon as the diagnosis is established
table_name: Recommendations for pulmonary arterial hypertension with signs of venous/

recommendation: In patients with PVOD/PCH, the use of drugs approved for PAH may be considered with careful monitoring of clinical symptoms and gas exchange
table_name: Recommendations for pulmonary arterial hypertension with signs of venous/

recommendation: Lung biopsy is not recommended to conﬁrm a diagnosis of PVOD/PCH
table_name: Recommendations for pulmonary arterial hypertension with signs of venous/

recommendation: Children It is recommended to perform the diagnostic work-up, including RHC and acute vasoreactivity testing, and treat children with PH at centres with speciﬁc expertise in paediatric PH
In children with PH, a comprehensive work-up for conﬁrming diagnosis and speciﬁc aetiology is recommended (similar to that in adults, but adapted for age)
For conﬁrming PH diagnosis, RHC is recommended, preferably before initiating any PAH therapy
In children with IPAH/HPAH, acute vasoreactivity testing is recommended to detect those who may beneﬁt from CCB therapy

It is recommended to similarly deﬁne a positive response to acute vasoreactivity testing in children and adults by a reduction in mPAP ≥10 mmHg to reach an absolute value of mPAP ≤40 mmHg, with an increased or unchanged CO
In children with PAH, a therapeutic strategy based on risk stratiﬁcation and treatment response is recommended, extrapolated from that in adults but adapted for age

It is recommended to monitor the treatment response in children with PAH by serially assessing a panel of data derived from clinical assessment, echocardiographic evaluation, biochemical markers, and exercise tolerance tests
Achieving and maintaining a low-risk proﬁle should be considered as an adequate treatment response for children with PAH
Infants It is recommended to screen infants with bronchopulmonary dysplasia for PH

In infants with (or at risk of) bronchopulmonary dysplasia and PH, treating lung disease—including hypoxia, aspiration, and structural airway disease —and optimizing respiratory support is recommended before initiating PAH therapy

It is recommended that PH centres provide care by a multidisciplinary team (cardiologist, pneumologist, rheumatologist, nurse specialist, radiologist, psychological and social work support, and appropriate on-call expertise)
It is recommended that PH centres have direct links and quick referral patterns to other services (such as genetic counselling, PEA/BPA, LTx, and adult congenital heart disease service)
It is recommended that PH centres maintain a patient registry
It is recommended that PH centres collaborate with patient associations
Accreditation of the PH centres should be considered (e.g. https://ec.europa.eu/health/ern/ assessment_en)
PH centres’ participation in collaborative clinical research should be considered

PH centres should follow-up a sufﬁcient number of patients to maintain expertise (at least 50 patients with PAH or CTEPH and at least two new referrals per month with documented PAH or CTEPH), and consider establishing collaborations with high-volume centres
It is recommended that public access deﬁbrillation be available at sites where cardiac arrest is more likely to occur.c,90–
table_name: Recommendations for public basic life support and access to automated external deﬁbrillators

recommendation: Prompt CPR by bystanders is recommended at OHCA.93–
table_name: Recommendations for public basic life support and access to automated external deﬁbrillators

recommendation: It is recommended to promote community training in basic life support to increase bystander CPR rate and AED use.
table_name: Recommendations for public basic life support and access to automated external deﬁbrillators

recommendation: Mobile phone-based alerting of basic life support-trained bystander volunteers to assist nearby OHCA victims should be considered.101–
table_name: Recommendations for public basic life support and access to automated external deﬁbrillators

recommendation: In patients with newly documented VA (frequent PVCs, NSVT, SMVT), a baseline 12-lead ECG, recording of the VA on 12-lead ECG, whenever possible, and an echocardiogram are recommended as ﬁrst-line evaluation.
table_name: Recommendations for evaluation of patients presenting with newly documented ventricular arrhythmia

recommendation: In patients with newly documented VA (frequent PVCs, NSVT, SMVT) and suspicion of SHD other than CAD after initial evaluation, a CMR should be considered.
table_name: Recommendations for evaluation of patients presenting with newly documented ventricular arrhythmia

recommendation: In patients with an incidental ﬁnding of a NSVT, a ≥24 h Holter ECG should be considered.
table_name: Recommendations for evaluation of patients presenting with newly documented ventricular arrhythmia

recommendation: Genetic testing is recommended when a condition is diagnosed in a living or deceased individual with a likely genetic basis and a risk of VA and SCD.
When a putative causative variant is ﬁrst identiﬁed, evaluation for pathogenicity is recommended using an internationally accepted framework.

When a Class IV or Class V variant has been identiﬁed in a living or deceased individual with a condition that carries a risk of VA and SCD, genetic testing of ﬁrst-degree and symptomatic relatives and obligate carriers is recommended.
It is recommended that genetic testing and counselling on its potential consequences should be undertaken by an expert multidisciplinary team.
It is recommended that Class III (variants of uncertain signiﬁcance) and Class IV variants should be evaluated for segregation in families where possible, and the variant re-evaluated periodically.
It is not recommended to undertake genetic testing in index patients with insufﬁcient evidence of a genetic disease.
In patients presenting with a ﬁrst SMVT episode, electrophysiological study, electroanatomical mapping, and mapping-guided biopsies may be considered for aetiological evaluation.197–
table_name: Recommendations for evaluation of patients presenting with a ﬁrst episode of sustained monomorphic ventricular tachycardia

recommendation: Diagnostic evaluation The investigation of a SCA survivor without obvious extra-cardiac cause is recommended to be overseen by a multidisciplinary team.177,251–
table_name: Recommendations for evaluation of sudden cardiac arrest survivors

recommendation: In electrically unstable patients after SCA, with suspicion of ongoing myocardial ischaemia, a coronary angiogram is indicated.
table_name: Recommendations for evaluation of sudden cardiac arrest survivors

recommendation: In SCA survivors, collection of blood samples at presentation is recommended for potential toxicology and genetic testing.
table_name: Recommendations for evaluation of sudden cardiac arrest survivors

recommendation: Retrieval of recordings from CIEDs and wearable monitors is recommended for all SCA survivors.
table_name: Recommendations for evaluation of sudden cardiac arrest survivors

recommendation: In SCA survivors, repeated 12-lead ECGs during stable rhythm (including high precordial lead ECG), as well as continuous cardiac monitoring, are recommended.
table_name: Recommendations for evaluation of sudden cardiac arrest survivors

recommendation: Echocardiography is recommended for evaluation of cardiac structure and function in all SCA survivors.
table_name: Recommendations for evaluation of sudden cardiac arrest survivors

recommendation: Coronary imaging and CMR with LGE are recommended for evaluation of cardiac structure and function in all SCA survivors without a clear underlying cause.
table_name: Recommendations for evaluation of sudden cardiac arrest survivors

recommendation: Sodium channel blocker test and exercise testing is recommended in SCA survivors without a clear underlying cause.117,222,258–
table_name: Recommendations for evaluation of sudden cardiac arrest survivors

recommendation: In SCA survivors, ergonovine, acetylcholine, or hyperventilation testing may be considered for the diagnosis of coronary vasospasm.
table_name: Recommendations for evaluation of sudden cardiac arrest survivors

recommendation: Investigation of unexpected SD, especially in case of suspicion of inherited disease, should be made a public health priority.
table_name: Recommendations for evaluation of sudden death victims

recommendation: In cases of SD, it is recommended to collect a detailed description of circumstances of death, symptoms prior to death, the family history, and to review prior medical ﬁles.
table_name: Recommendations for evaluation of sudden death victims

recommendation: A comprehensive autopsy is recommended, ideally, in all cases of unexpected SD, and always in those ,50 years of age.
table_name: Recommendations for evaluation of sudden death victims

recommendation: In cases of SCD, it is recommended to retain samples suitable for DNA extraction and consult a cardiac pathologist when an inherited cause is suspected or the cause of death unexplained.
table_name: Recommendations for evaluation of sudden death victims

recommendation: Toxicology screens are recommended in SD cases with uncertain cause of death.
table_name: Recommendations for evaluation of sudden death victims

recommendation: For SCD where the cause is known or suspected to be heritable, genetic testing targeted to the cause is recommended.
table_name: Recommendations for evaluation of sudden death victims

recommendation: Following SADS, post-mortem genetic testing targeted to primary electrical disease is recommended when the decedent is young (,50) and/or the circumstances and/or family history support a primary electrical disease.
table_name: Recommendations for evaluation of sudden death victims

recommendation: When an autopsy diagnoses possible heritable cardiac disease, it is recommended to refer ﬁrst-degree relatives for cardiac assessment in a specialized clinic.
table_name: Recommendations for evaluation of sudden death victims

recommendation: In non-autopsied cases of SD where inherited cardiac disease is suspected, it is recommended to refer ﬁrst-degree relatives for cardiac assessment in a specialized clinic.
table_name: Recommendations for evaluation of sudden death victims

recommendation: Following SADS, post-mortem genetic testing in the decedent for additional genes may be considered.
table_name: Recommendations for evaluation of sudden death victims

recommendation: Following SADS, hypothesis-free post-mortem genetic testing using exome or genome sequencing is not recommended.
table_name: Recommendations for evaluation of sudden death victims

recommendation: Familial evaluation of SADS decedents is recommended: • for ﬁrst-degree relatives • for relatives who must carry a mutation based on analysis of the family history • for relatives with suspicious symptoms • when the decedent’s age is ,50 years, or if there is other circumstantial data or family history to suggest heritable disease.
table_name: Recommendations for evaluation of relatives of sudden arrhythmic death syndrome decedents

recommendation: Familial evaluation of SADS decedents is recommended to include genetic testing when post-mortem genetic testing in a SADS decedent detects a pathogenic mutation.
table_name: Recommendations for evaluation of relatives of sudden arrhythmic death syndrome decedents

recommendation: Baseline familial evaluation of SADS decedents is recommended to include taking a medical history and performing physical examination, standard and high precordial lead ECG, echocardiography, and exercise testing.
table_name: Recommendations for evaluation of relatives of sudden arrhythmic death syndrome decedents

recommendation: In SADS families without a diagnosis after clinical evaluation, follow-up is recommended for children of decedents until they reach adulthood.
table_name: Recommendations for evaluation of relatives of sudden arrhythmic death syndrome decedents

recommendation: Pharmacological testing with a sodium channel blocker should be considered in relatives of SADS decedents who are 16 years or older when baseline testing and/or proband ﬁndings increase the suspicion of BrS.
table_name: Recommendations for evaluation of relatives of sudden arrhythmic death syndrome decedents

recommendation: Pharmacological testing including epinephrine challenge (if exercise testing is impractical) and sodium channel blocker challenge may be considered in ﬁrst-degree relatives of SADS decedents with normal baseline testing.
table_name: Recommendations for evaluation of relatives of sudden arrhythmic death syndrome decedents

recommendation: In SADS families without a diagnosis after clinical evaluation, follow-up is not recommended for asymptomatic adults who can be discharged with advice to return if they develop symptoms or if the family history changes.
table_name: Recommendations for evaluation of relatives of sudden arrhythmic death syndrome decedents

recommendation: Withdrawal of offending agents is recommended whenever drug-induced VAs are suspected.
table_name: Recommendations for treatment of reversible conditions

recommendation: Investigation for reversible causes (e.g. electrolyte imbalances, ischaemia, hypoxaemia, fever)c is recommended in patients with VA.
table_name: Recommendations for treatment of reversible conditions

recommendation: Despite a possible correctable cause for the presenting VA, the need for ICD implantation should be considered based on an individual evaluation of the risk of subsequent VA/ SCD.
table_name: Recommendations for treatment of reversible conditions

recommendation: Acute management of sustained VT DC cardioversion is recommended as the ﬁrst-line treatment for patients with haemodynamically not-tolerated SMVT.
table_name: Recommendations for the acute management of sustained ventricular tachycardia and electrical storm

recommendation: DC cardioversion is recommended as the ﬁrst-line treatment for patients presenting with tolerated SMVT provided that the anaesthetic/ sedation risk is low.
table_name: Recommendations for the acute management of sustained ventricular tachycardia and electrical storm

recommendation: In patients presenting with a regular haemodynamically tolerated wide QRS complex tachycardia suspected for SVT, administration of adenosine or vagal manoeuvres should be considered.
table_name: Recommendations for the acute management of sustained ventricular tachycardia and electrical storm

recommendation: In patients presenting with a haemodynamically tolerated SMVT and known or suspected SHD, intravenous procainamide should be considered.
table_name: Recommendations for the acute management of sustained ventricular tachycardia and electrical storm

recommendation: In patients presenting with a haemodynamically tolerated SMVT in the absence of an established diagnosis, intravenous amiodarone may be considered.
table_name: Recommendations for the acute management of sustained ventricular tachycardia and electrical storm

recommendation: In patients presenting with a haemodynamically tolerated SMVT in the absence of signiﬁcant SHD, ﬂecainide, ajmaline, or sotalol may be considered.
table_name: Recommendations for the acute management of sustained ventricular tachycardia and electrical storm

recommendation: Intravenous verapamil is not recommended in broad QRS complex tachycardia of unknown mechanism.
table_name: Recommendations for the acute management of sustained ventricular tachycardia and electrical storm

recommendation: Management of electrical storm Mild to moderate sedation is recommended in patients with electrical storm to alleviate psychological distress and reduce sympathetic tone.
table_name: Recommendations for the acute management of sustained ventricular tachycardia and electrical storm

recommendation: Antiarrhythmic therapy with beta-blockers (non-selective preferred) in combination with intravenous amiodarone is recommended in patients with SHD and electrical storm unless contraindicated.
table_name: Recommendations for the acute management of sustained ventricular tachycardia and electrical storm

recommendation: Intravenous magnesium with supplementation of potassium is recommended in patients with TdP.
table_name: Recommendations for the acute management of sustained ventricular tachycardia and electrical storm

recommendation: Isoproterenol or transvenous pacing to increase heart rate is recommended in patients with acquired LQT syndrome and recurrent TdP despite correction of precipitating conditions and magnesium.
table_name: Recommendations for the acute management of sustained ventricular tachycardia and electrical storm

recommendation: Catheter ablation is recommended in patients presenting with incessant VT or electrical storm due to SMVT refractory to AADs.
table_name: Recommendations for the acute management of sustained ventricular tachycardia and electrical storm

recommendation: Deep sedation/intubation should be considered in patients with an intractable electrical storm refractory to drug treatment.
table_name: Recommendations for the acute management of sustained ventricular tachycardia and electrical storm

recommendation: Catheter ablation should be considered in patients with recurrent episodes of PVT/VF triggered by a similar PVC, non-responsive to medical treatment or coronary revascularization.
table_name: Recommendations for the acute management of sustained ventricular tachycardia and electrical storm

recommendation: Quinidine may be considered in patients with CAD and electrical storm due to recurrent PVT when other AAD therapy fails.
table_name: Recommendations for the acute management of sustained ventricular tachycardia and electrical storm

recommendation: Institution of mechanical circulatory support may be considered in the management of drug-refractory electrical storm and cardiogenic shock.
table_name: Recommendations for the acute management of sustained ventricular tachycardia and electrical storm

recommendation: Optimal medical treatment including ACE-I/ARB/ ARNIs, MRAs, beta-blockers, and SGLT2 inhibitors is indicated in all heart failure patients with reduced EF.343–
table_name: Recommendations for treatment with heart failure medication

recommendation: ICD implantation is recommended in patients with documented VF or haemodynamically not-tolerated VT in the absence of reversible causes.349–
table_name: Recommendations for secondary prevention of sudden cardiac death*

recommendation: In patients with VT/VF, an indication for ICD, and no contraindication for amiodarone, amiodarone may be considered when an ICD is not available, contraindicated for concurrent medical reasons, or declined by the patient.
table_name: Recommendations for secondary prevention of sudden cardiac death*

recommendation: In patients with SMVT or SPVT/VF triggered by a PVC with similar morphology and an indication for ICD, catheter ablation may be considered when an ICD is not available, contraindicated for concurrent medical reasons, or declined by the patient.
table_name: Recommendations for secondary prevention of sudden cardiac death*

recommendation: When an ICD is indicated, it is recommended to evaluate whether the patient could beneﬁt from CRT-deﬁbrillator.
table_name: Recommendations for adding cardiac resynchronization therapy to implantable cardioverter deﬁbrillator

recommendation: (general aspects) Implantation of a cardioverter deﬁbrillator is only recommended in patients who have an expectation of good quality survival .1 year.
table_name: Recommendations for implantable cardioverter deﬁbrillator implantation

recommendation: It is not recommended to implant an ICD in patients with incessant VAs until the VA is controlled.
table_name: Recommendations for implantable cardioverter deﬁbrillator implantation

recommendation: The WCD should be considered for adult patients with a secondary prevention ICD indication, who are temporarily not candidates for ICD implantation.

Subcutaneous deﬁbrillator should be considered as an alternative to transvenous deﬁbrillator in patients with an indication for an ICD when pacing therapy for bradycardia, cardiac resynchronization, or ATP is not needed.
table_name: Recommendations for subcutaneous implantable cardioverter deﬁbrillator

recommendation: Optimization of ICD programming is indicated to avoid inappropriate and unnecessary therapies and to reduce mortality.373–
table_name: Recommendations for optimization of device programming

recommendation: Programming of prolonged detection settings is indicated (duration criteria of at least 6–12 s or 30 intervals).
table_name: Recommendations for optimization of device programming

recommendation: It is recommended to program the slowest tachycardia therapy zone limit ≥188 b.p.m. in primary prevention ICD patients.
table_name: Recommendations for optimization of device programming

recommendation: In patients with SHD, programming of at least one ATP therapy is recommended in all tachyarrhythmias zones.
table_name: Recommendations for optimization of device programming

recommendation: It is recommended to program algorithms for SVT vs. VT discrimination for tachycardias with rates up to 230 b.p.m.383–
table_name: Recommendations for optimization of device programming

recommendation: It is recommended to activate lead failure alerts.397–
table_name: Recommendations for optimization of device programming

recommendation: Remote monitoring is recommended to reduce the incidence of inappropriate shocks.
table_name: Recommendations for optimization of device programming

recommendation: Programming of burst ATP as ﬁrst attempt is recommended over ramp ATP.
table_name: Recommendations for optimization of device programming

recommendation: For S-ICDs, a dual detection zone conﬁguration is recommended with activation of discrimination algorithm in the lower conditional shock zone.388–
table_name: Recommendations for optimization of device programming

recommendation: For routine ICD programming, activation of more than one tachycardia detection zone should be considered.
table_name: Recommendations for optimization of device programming

recommendation: Catheter ablation is recommended for ICD patients with recurrent SVT resulting in inappropriate ICD therapies.
table_name: Recommendations for concomitant treatment to avoid inappropriate implantable cardioverter deﬁbrillator therapy

recommendation: Pharmacological treatment or catheter ablation is recommended in patients with AF-related inappropriate ICD therapies despite optimal ICD programming.
table_name: Recommendations for concomitant treatment to avoid inappropriate implantable cardioverter deﬁbrillator therapy

recommendation: Assessment of psychological status and treatment of distress is recommended in ICD patients.421–
table_name: Recommendations for psychosocial management after implantable cardioverter deﬁbrillator implantation

recommendation: Communication between patient and physician/ healthcare professional is recommended to address ICD-related concerns and to discuss quality-of-life issues before ICD implantation and during disease progression.
table_name: Recommendations for psychosocial management after implantable cardioverter deﬁbrillator implantation

recommendation: ICD implantation should be considered in LVAD recipients with symptomatic sustained VAs.
table_name: Recommendations for implantable cardioverter deﬁbrillator implantation in left ventricular assist device recipients

recommendation: Informed discussion with patient and family about ICD deactivation options and shared decision-making is indicated prior to implantation and in case of signiﬁcant health status deterioration.
table_name: Recommendations for end-of-life issues in implantable cardioverter deﬁbrillator carriers

recommendation: Single-chamber ICD is recommended over dual-chamber ICD in primary prevention patients without current or expected indication for atrial or AV sequential pacing due to a lower risk of device-related complications.
table_name: Recommendations for prevention of implantable cardioverter deﬁbrillator complications

recommendation: The use of single-coil leads over dual-coil ICD leads should be considered due to lower complication rate during transvenous lead extraction.
table_name: Recommendations for prevention of implantable cardioverter deﬁbrillator complications

recommendation: Treatment of VAs in ACS Intravenous beta-blocker treatment is indicated for patients with recurrent PVT/VF during STEMI unless contraindicated.
table_name: Recommendations for treatment of ventricular arrhythmias in acute coronary syndrome and vasospasm

recommendation: Intravenous amiodarone treatment should be considered for patients with recurrent PVT/VF during the acute phase of ACS.
table_name: Recommendations for treatment of ventricular arrhythmias in acute coronary syndrome and vasospasm

recommendation: Intravenous lidocaine may be considered for the treatment of recurrent PVT/VF not responding to beta-blockers or amiodarone, or if amiodarone is contraindicated during the acute phase of ACS.
table_name: Recommendations for treatment of ventricular arrhythmias in acute coronary syndrome and vasospasm

recommendation: Prophylactic treatment with AADs (other than beta-blockers) is not recommended in ACS.
table_name: Recommendations for treatment of ventricular arrhythmias in acute coronary syndrome and vasospasm

recommendation: Vasospasm In SCA survivors with coronary artery spasm, implantation of an ICD should be considered.562–
table_name: Recommendations for treatment of ventricular arrhythmias in acute coronary syndrome and vasospasm

recommendation: Risk stratiﬁcation Early (before discharge) assessment of LVEF is recommended in all patients with acute MI.
table_name: Recommendations for risk stratiﬁcation and treatment of ventricular arrhythmias early after myocardial infarction

recommendation: In patients with pre-discharge LVEF ≤40%, re-evaluation of LVEF 6–12 weeks after MI is recommended to assess the potential need for primary prevention ICD implantation.
table_name: Recommendations for risk stratiﬁcation and treatment of ventricular arrhythmias early after myocardial infarction

recommendation: Treatment of VAs Catheter ablation should be considered in patients with recurrent episodes of PVT/VF triggered by a similar PVC non-responsive to medical treatment or coronary revascularization in the subacute phase of MI.
table_name: Recommendations for risk stratiﬁcation and treatment of ventricular arrhythmias early after myocardial infarction

recommendation: and treatment of ventricular arrhythmias in chronic coronary artery disease Risk stratiﬁcation and primary prevention of SCD In patients with syncope and previous STEMI, PES is indicated when syncope remains unexplained after non-invasive evaluation.
table_name: Recommendations for risk stratiﬁcation, sudden cardiac death prevention,

recommendation: ICD therapy is recommended in patients with CAD, symptomatic heart failure (NYHA class II–III), and LVEF ≤35% despite ≥3 months of OMT.
table_name: Recommendations for risk stratiﬁcation, sudden cardiac death prevention,

recommendation: ICD therapy should be considered in patients with CAD, NYHA class I, and LVEF ≤30% despite ≥3 months of OMT.
table_name: Recommendations for risk stratiﬁcation, sudden cardiac death prevention,

recommendation: ICD implantation should be considered in patients with CAD, LVEF ≤40% despite ≥3 months of OMT, and NSVT, if they are inducible for SMVT by PES.
table_name: Recommendations for risk stratiﬁcation, sudden cardiac death prevention,

recommendation: In patients with CAD, prophylactic treatment with AADs other than beta-blockers is not recommended.
table_name: Recommendations for risk stratiﬁcation, sudden cardiac death prevention,
