recommendation: Secondary prevention of SCD and treatment of VAs ICD implantation is recommended in patients without ongoing ischaemia with documented VF or haemodynamically not-tolerated VT occurring later than 48 h after MI.349–
table_name: Recommendations for risk stratiﬁcation, sudden cardiac death prevention,

recommendation: In patients with CAD and recurrent, symptomatic SMVT, or ICD shocks for SMVT despite chronic amiodarone therapy, catheter ablation is recommended in preference to escalating AAD therapy.
table_name: Recommendations for risk stratiﬁcation, sudden cardiac death prevention,

recommendation: In patients with CAD and haemodynamically well-tolerated SMVT and LVEF ≥40%, catheter ablationinexperiencedcentresshouldbeconsidered as an alternative to ICD therapy, provided that established endpoints have been reached.c
table_name: Recommendations for risk stratiﬁcation, sudden cardiac death prevention,

recommendation: ICD implantation should be considered in patients with a haemodynamically tolerated SMVT and an LVEF ≥40% if VT ablation fails, is not available, or is not desired.
table_name: Recommendations for risk stratiﬁcation, sudden cardiac death prevention,

recommendation: Catheter ablation should be considered in patients with CAD and recurrent, symptomatic SMVT, or ICD shocks for SMVT despite beta-blockers or sotalol treatment.
table_name: Recommendations for risk stratiﬁcation, sudden cardiac death prevention,

recommendation: In patients with CAD eligible for ICD implantation, catheter ablation may be considered just before (or immediately after) ICD implantation to decrease subsequent VT burden and ICD shocks.
table_name: Recommendations for risk stratiﬁcation, sudden cardiac death prevention,

recommendation: Diagnostic evaluation Cardiac stress imaging during physical exercise is recommended in addition to cardiopulmonary exercise test in patients with anomalous aortic origin of a coronary artery with an interarterial course to conﬁrm/exclude myocardial ischaemia.
table_name: Recommendations for sudden cardiac death prevention in patients with coronary anomalies

recommendation: Cardiac stress imaging during physical exercise is recommended in addition to cardiopulmonary exercise test after surgery in patients with anomalous aortic origin of a coronary artery with a history of aborted CA.
table_name: Recommendations for sudden cardiac death prevention in patients with coronary anomalies

recommendation: Treatment Surgery is recommended in patients with anomalous aortic origin of a coronary artery with CA, syncope suspected to be due to VAs, or angina when other causes have been excluded.
table_name: Recommendations for sudden cardiac death prevention in patients with coronary anomalies

recommendation: Surgery should be considered in asymptomatic patients with anomalous aortic origin of a coronary artery and evidence of myocardial ischaemia or abnormal aortic origin of the left coronary artery with high-risk anatomy.c
table_name: Recommendations for sudden cardiac death prevention in patients with coronary anomalies

recommendation: General recommendations Regular assessment of ventricular function of patients with PVC burden .10% and normal ventricular function is indicated.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with idiopathic premature ventricular complexes/ventricular tachycardia

recommendation: In patients with PVCs/VT and a presentation not typical for an idiopathic origin,c CMR should be considered, despite a normal echocardiogram.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with idiopathic premature ventricular complexes/ventricular tachycardia

recommendation: Treatment Catheter ablation as ﬁrst-line treatment is recommended for symptomatic idiopathic VT/ PVCs from the RVOT or the left fascicles.d
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with idiopathic premature ventricular complexes/ventricular tachycardia

recommendation: Beta-blockers or non-dihydropyridine CCBs are indicated in symptomatic patients with idiopathic VT/PVCs from an origin other than the RVOT or the left fascicles.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with idiopathic premature ventricular complexes/ventricular tachycardia

recommendation: Beta-blockers, non-dihydropyridine CCBs, or ﬂecainide should be considered when catheter ablation is not available, desired, or is particularly risky in symptomatic patients with idiopathic VT/ PVCs from the RVOT or the left fascicles.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with idiopathic premature ventricular complexes/ventricular tachycardia

recommendation: Catheter ablation or ﬂecainide should be considered in symptomatic patients with idiopathic VT/PVCs from an origin other than the RVOT or the left fascicles.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with idiopathic premature ventricular complexes/ventricular tachycardia

recommendation: Catheter ablation may be considered for idiopathic VT/PVCs in asymptomatic patients with repeatedly more than 20% of PVCs per day at follow-up.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with idiopathic premature ventricular complexes/ventricular tachycardia

recommendation: Catheter ablation of idiopathic VT/PVCs is not recommended in children ,5 years of age or ,10 kg weight except when previous medical therapy fails or when VT is not haemodynamically tolerated.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with idiopathic premature ventricular complexes/ventricular tachycardia

recommendation: Amiodarone as a ﬁrst-line treatment is not recommended in patients with idiopathic VTs/ PVCs.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with idiopathic premature ventricular complexes/ventricular tachycardia

recommendation: Verapamil is not recommended in children ,1 year of age with PVC/VT, particularly if they have signs of heart failure or concurrent use of other AADs.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with idiopathic premature ventricular complexes/ventricular tachycardia

recommendation: Recommendation Diagnostic evaluation In patients with an unexplained reduced EF and a PVC burden of at least 10%, PVC-induced cardiomyopathy should be considered.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with premature ventricular complex-induced or premature ventricular complexaggravated cardiomyopathy

recommendation: In patients with suspected PVC-induced cardiomyopathy, CMR should be considered.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with premature ventricular complex-induced or premature ventricular complexaggravated cardiomyopathy

recommendation: Treatment In patients with a cardiomyopathy suspected to be caused by frequent and predominately monomorphic PVCs, catheter ablation is recommended.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with premature ventricular complex-induced or premature ventricular complexaggravated cardiomyopathy

recommendation: In patients with SHD in whom predominately monomorphic frequent PVCs are suspected to be contributing to the cardiomyopathy, AAD (amiodarone) treatment or catheter ablation should be considered.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with premature ventricular complex-induced or premature ventricular complexaggravated cardiomyopathy

recommendation: In non-responders to CRT with frequent, predominately monomorphic PVCs limiting optimal biventricular pacing despite pharmacological therapy, catheter ablation or AADs should be considered.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with premature ventricular complex-induced or premature ventricular complexaggravated cardiomyopathy

recommendation: Recommendation Diagnostic evaluation and general recommendations Genetic testing (including at least LMNA, PLN, RBM20, and FLNC genes) is recommended in patients with DCM/HNDCM and AV conduction delay at ,50 years, or who have a family history of DCM/HNDCM or SCD in a ﬁrst-degree relative (at age ,50 years).641–
table_name: Recommendations for risk stratiﬁcation, sudden cardiac death prevention, and treatment of ventricular arrhythmias in dilated cardiomyopathy/hypokinetic non-dilated cardiomyopathy

recommendation: CMR with LGE should be considered in DCM/ HNDCM patients for assessing the aetiology and the risk of VA/SCD.
table_name: Recommendations for risk stratiﬁcation, sudden cardiac death prevention, and treatment of ventricular arrhythmias in dilated cardiomyopathy/hypokinetic non-dilated cardiomyopathy

recommendation: Genetic testing (including at least LMNA, PLN, RBM20, and FLNC genes) should be considered for risk stratiﬁcation in patients with apparently sporadic DCM/HNDCM, who present at young age, or with signs suspicious for an inherited aetiology.641–
table_name: Recommendations for risk stratiﬁcation, sudden cardiac death prevention, and treatment of ventricular arrhythmias in dilated cardiomyopathy/hypokinetic non-dilated cardiomyopathy

recommendation: Participation in high-intensity exercise including competitive sports is not recommended for individuals with DCM/HNDCM and a LMNA mutation.
table_name: Recommendations for risk stratiﬁcation, sudden cardiac death prevention, and treatment of ventricular arrhythmias in dilated cardiomyopathy/hypokinetic non-dilated cardiomyopathy

recommendation: Risk stratiﬁcation and primary prevention of SCD ICD implantation should be considered in patients with DCM/HNDCM, symptomatic heart failure (NYHA class II–III), and LVEF ≤35% after ≥3 months of OMT.
table_name: Recommendations for risk stratiﬁcation, sudden cardiac death prevention, and treatment of ventricular arrhythmias in dilated cardiomyopathy/hypokinetic non-dilated cardiomyopathy

recommendation: ICD implantation should be considered in DCM/ HNDCM patients with a pathogenic mutation in LMNA gene, if the estimated 5-year risk of life-threatening VA is ≥10%c and in the presence of NSVT or LVEF , 50% or AV conduction delay.
table_name: Recommendations for risk stratiﬁcation, sudden cardiac death prevention, and treatment of ventricular arrhythmias in dilated cardiomyopathy/hypokinetic non-dilated cardiomyopathy

recommendation: ICD implantation should be considered in DCM/ HNDCM patients with a LVEF ,50% and ≥2 risk factors (syncope, LGE on CMR, inducible SMVT at PES, pathogenic mutations in LMNA,d PLN, FLNC, and RBM20 genes).
table_name: Recommendations for risk stratiﬁcation, sudden cardiac death prevention, and treatment of ventricular arrhythmias in dilated cardiomyopathy/hypokinetic non-dilated cardiomyopathy

recommendation: In DCM/HNDM patients, electrophysiological evaluation should be considered when syncope remains unexplained after non-invasive evaluation.

recommendation: Mexiletine is indicated in LQT3 patients with a prolonged QT interval.

recommendation: Beta-blockers should be considered in patients with a pathogenic mutation and a normal QTc interval.

table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with long QT syndrome

table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with long QT syndrome

recommendation: In LQTS, it should be considered to calculate the arrhythmic risk before initiation of therapy based on the genotype and the duration of QTc interval.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with long QT syndrome

recommendation: Invasive electrophysiologic study is not recommended in LQTS.

table_name: Recommendations for management of patients with

table_name: Recommendations for management of patients with

table_name: Recommendations for management of patients with

recommendation: ICD implantation may be considered in patients with Andersen–Tawil syndrome who have a history of unexplained syncope or suffer from tolerated sustained VT.

recommendation: Diagnosis It is recommended that BrS is diagnosed in patients with no other heart disease and a spontaneous type 1 Brugada ECG pattern.974–
table_name: Recommendations for management of patients with Brugada syndrome

recommendation: Genetic testing for SCN5A gene is recommended for probands with BrS.
table_name: Recommendations for management of patients with Brugada syndrome

recommendation: BrS should be considered in patients with no other heart disease and induced type 1 Brugada pattern who have at least one of: • Arrhythmic syncope or nocturnal agonal respiration • A family history of BrS • A family history of SD (,45 years old) with a negative autopsy and circumstance suspicious for BrS.

table_name: Recommendations for management of patients with Brugada syndrome

recommendation: General recommendations The following is recommended in all patients with BrS: (a) Avoidance of drugs that may induce ST-segment elevation in right precordial leads (http://www.brugadadrugs.org). (b) Avoidance of cocaine, cannabis, and excessive alcohol intake. (c) Treatment of fever with antipyretic drugs.
table_name: Recommendations for management of patients with Brugada syndrome

recommendation: Risk stratiﬁcation, prevention of SCD and treatment of VA ICD implantation is recommended in patients with BrS who: (a) Are survivors of an aborted CA and/or (b) Have documented spontaneous sustained VT.980,990–
table_name: Recommendations for management of patients with Brugada syndrome

recommendation: ICD implantation should be considered in patients with type 1 Brugada pattern and an arrhythmic syncope.
table_name: Recommendations for management of patients with Brugada syndrome

recommendation: Implantation of a loop recorder should be considered in BrS patients with an unexplained syncope.
table_name: Recommendations for management of patients with Brugada syndrome

recommendation: Quinidine should be considered in patients with BrS who qualify for an ICD but have a contraindication, decline, or have recurrent ICD shocks.
table_name: Recommendations for management of patients with Brugada syndrome

recommendation: Isoproterenol infusion should be considered in BrS patients suffering electrical storm.
table_name: Recommendations for management of patients with Brugada syndrome

recommendation: Catheter ablation of triggering PVCs and/or RVOT epicardial substrate should be considered in BrS patients with recurrent appropriate ICD shocks refractory to drug therapy.1010–
table_name: Recommendations for management of patients with Brugada syndrome

recommendation: PES may be considered in asymptomatic patients with a spontaneous type I BrS ECG.
table_name: Recommendations for management of patients with Brugada syndrome

recommendation: ICD implantation may be considered in selected asymptomatic BrS patients with inducible VF during PES using up to 2 extra stimuli.
table_name: Recommendations for management of patients with Brugada syndrome

recommendation: Catheter ablation in asymptomatic BrS patients is not recommended.
table_name: Recommendations for management of patients with Brugada syndrome

recommendation: It is recommended that the ERS is diagnosed in a patient resuscitated from unexplained VF/PVT in the presence of ERP.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with early repolarization pattern/syndrome

recommendation: In an SCD victim with a negative autopsy and medical chart review, and an ante-mortem ECG demonstrating the ERP, the diagnosis of ERS should be considered.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with early repolarization pattern/syndrome

recommendation: First-degree relatives of ERS patients should be considered for clinical evaluation for ERP with additional high-risk features.c
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with early repolarization pattern/syndrome

recommendation: Clinical evaluation is not recommended routinely in asymptomatic subjects with ERP.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with early repolarization pattern/syndrome

recommendation: Risk stratiﬁcation, prevention of SCD and treatment of VA ICD implantation is recommended in patients with a diagnosis of ERS who have survived a CA.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with early repolarization pattern/syndrome

recommendation: Isoproterenol infusion should be considered for ERS patients with electrical storm.1017,1030–
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with early repolarization pattern/syndrome

recommendation: Quinidine in addition to an ICD should be considered for recurrent VF in ERS patients.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with early repolarization pattern/syndrome

recommendation: ILR should be considered in individuals with ERP and at least one risk featured or arrhythmic syncope.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with early repolarization pattern/syndrome

recommendation: PVC ablation should be considered in ERS patients with recurrent VF episodes triggered by a similar PVC non-responsive to medical treatment.

recommendation: ICD implantation or quinidine may be considered in individuals with ERP and arrhythmic syncope and additional risk features.d
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with early repolarization pattern/syndrome

recommendation: ICD implantation is not recommended in asymptomatic patients with an isolated ERP.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with early repolarization pattern/syndrome

recommendation: Diagnosis It is recommended that CPVT is diagnosed in the presence of a structurally normal heart, normal ECG, and exercise- or emotion-induced bidirectional, or PVT.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with catecholaminergic polymorphic ventricular tachycardia

recommendation: It is recommended that CPVT is diagnosed in patients who are carriers of a mutation in disease-causing genes.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with catecholaminergic polymorphic ventricular tachycardia

recommendation: Genetic testing and genetic counselling are indicated in patients with clinical suspicion or clinical diagnosis of CPVT.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with catecholaminergic polymorphic ventricular tachycardia

recommendation: Epinephrine or isoproterenol challenge may be considered for the diagnosis of CPVT when an exercise test is not possible.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with catecholaminergic polymorphic ventricular tachycardia

recommendation: General recommendations Avoidance of competitive sports, strenuous exercise, and exposure to stressful environments is recommended in all patients with CPVT.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with catecholaminergic polymorphic ventricular tachycardia

recommendation: Therapeutic interventions Beta-blockers, ideally non-selective (nadolol or propranolol) are recommended in all patients with a clinical diagnosis of CPVT.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with catecholaminergic polymorphic ventricular tachycardia

recommendation: ICD implantation combined with beta-blockers and ﬂecainide is recommended in CPVT patients after aborted CA.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with catecholaminergic polymorphic ventricular tachycardia

recommendation: LCSD should be considered in patients with diagnosis of CPVT when the combination of beta-blockers and ﬂecainide at therapeutic dosage are either not effective, not tolerated, or contraindicated.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with catecholaminergic polymorphic ventricular tachycardia

recommendation: ICD implantation should be considered in patients with CPVT who experience arrhythmogenic syncope and/or documented bidirectional/PVT while on highest tolerated beta-blocker dose and on ﬂecainide.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with catecholaminergic polymorphic ventricular tachycardia

recommendation: Flecainide should be considered in patients with CPVT who experience recurrent syncope, polymorphic/bidirectional VT, or persistent exertional PVCs, while on beta-blockers at the highest tolerated dose.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with catecholaminergic polymorphic ventricular tachycardia

recommendation: PES is not recommended for stratiﬁcation of SCD risk.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with catecholaminergic polymorphic ventricular tachycardia

recommendation: Diagnosis It is recommended that SQTS is diagnosed in the presence of a QTc ≤360 ms and one or more of the following: (a) a pathogenic mutation, (b) a family history of SQTS, (c) survival from a VT/VF episode in the absence of heart disease.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with short QT syndrome

recommendation: Genetic testing is indicated in patients diagnosed with SQTS.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with short QT syndrome

recommendation: SQTS should be considered in the presence of a QTc ≥320 ms and ≤360 ms and arrhythmic syncope.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with short QT syndrome

recommendation: SQTS may be considered in the presence of a QTc ≥320 ms and ≤360 ms and a family history of SD at age ,40 years.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with short QT syndrome

recommendation: Risk stratiﬁcation, SCD prevention and treatment of VA ICD implantation is recommended in patients with a diagnosis of SQTS who: (a) are survivors of an aborted CA and/or (b) have documented spontaneous sustained VT.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with short QT syndrome

recommendation: ILR should be considered in young SQTS patients.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with short QT syndrome

recommendation: ICD implantation should be considered in SQTS patients with arrhythmic syncope.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with short QT syndrome

recommendation: Quinidine may be considered in (a) SQTS patients who qualify for an ICD but present a contraindication to the ICD or refuse it, and (b) asymptomatic SQTS patients and a family history of SCD.1069–
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with short QT syndrome

recommendation: Isoproterenol may be considered in SQTS patients with an electrical storm.
table_name: Recommendations for the management of patients with short QT syndrome

recommendation: PES is not recommended for SCD risk stratiﬁcation in SQTS patients.

recommendation: Acute management of VA During pregnancy, electrical cardioversion is recommended for sustained VT.

recommendation: For acute conversion of haemodynamically tolerated SMVT during pregnancy, a beta-blocker, sotalol, ﬂecainide, procainamide, or overdrive ventricular pacing should be considered.

recommendation: Long-term management of VA If ICD implantation is indicated during pregnancy, implantation is recommended with optimal radiation protection.

recommendation: Continuation of beta-blockers is recommended during pregnancy and post-partum in women with LQTS or CPVT.955,1094–

recommendation: Continuation of beta-blockers should be considered during pregnancy in women with ARVC.1097–
table_name: Recommendations for the prevention of sudden cardiac death and management of ventricular arrhythmia during pregnancy

recommendation: Oral metoprolol, propranolol, or verapamil should be considered for long-term management of idiopathic sustained VT during pregnancy.
table_name: Recommendations for the prevention of sudden cardiac death and management of ventricular arrhythmia during pregnancy

recommendation: Catheter ablation using non-ﬂuoroscopic mapping systems should be considered, preferably after the ﬁrst trimester, in women with highly symptomatic recurrent SMVT refractory or who are intolerant to AADs.

recommendation: Prior to heart transplant In patients awaiting heart transplantation, ICD implantation for primary prevention should be considered.

recommendation: In patients awaiting heart transplantation, WCD may be considered.

recommendation: In athletes with positive medical history, abnormal physical examination, or ECG alterations, further investigations including echocardiography and/or CMR to conﬁrm (or exclude) an underlying disease are recommended.

recommendation: It is recommended that athletes diagnosed with a cardiovascular disease associated with SCD are managed according to current guidelines for sports eligibility.

recommendation: It is recommended that staff at sporting facilities are trained in CPR and in the use of AED.

recommendation: Pre-participation cardiovascular evaluation of competitive athletes should be considered.

recommendation: It should be considered that cardiovascular evaluation of young (,35 years) competitive athletes includes history, physical examination, and 12-lead ECG.
